story:
Hopkinton is very fortunate to have two Destination Imagination teams win the Massachusetts State Championships (www.MADIkids.org) for their challenges and these teams have been invited to compete at the Destination Imagination Global Final competition (www.globalfinals2014.org) in Knoxville, TN, May 21-24.  Congratulations to the 7th grade Middle School team of Aren Arakelian, Neal Patel, Patrick Webb, Austin Marques, Izzy Puri, Niha Gopi, Eva Kuruvilla (Team Manager: Leda Arakelian) and to the 5th grade Hopkins School team of Elizabeth Kane, Tara Joshi, Paige Lavelanet, Ceara Perry, Mia Sannicandro, Vani Sharma, Sara Bernardo (Team Manager: Cindy Bernardo - Co Manager: Haley Bernardo.)  These kids have worked very hard for several months on their community service projects (benefiting the Hopkinton Senior Center, Golden Pond, and Soldier’s Angels) – and after all that hard work and practice, they each won the regional tournament in Uxbridge and won their challenges at the MA state championships.  Their hard work has paid off, and they are now invited to compete internationally at the DI Global Finals.

Attending Global Finals is a huge opportunity for these students.  The week includes not only the DI competition for their central challenges and instant challenges, but also includes several learning opportunities including an Innovation Expo and interaction opportunities with National Geographic and NASA.   For the kids, this is a once in a lifetime opportunity. 

However, the cost to travel and attend the competition seems insurmountable, and we are hoping that we can raise funds to cover or defray these costs.  Hopkinton hopes to send two teams, each of seven children, with one parent to accompany each child.  The cost of the registration fees, housing, airfare, transfers, for the two teams is well in excess of $40,000!

We are reaching out to our community to help us fund this opportunity for them.  A donation in any amount would be greatly appreciated.  The children will be holding various fundraising events to help them get to Knoxville, and the first of these is this on-line donation page.

Thank you very much in advance for supporting these wonderful, gifted, and community-minded children!  It is very much appreciated.

story: Well, it's fallen on us...unfortunately, Karim will drop out of college if we don't raise this money by the end of the week. Everything counts guys, let's do it for him.

story:
In continuing to operate Bubbles Academy throughout this pandemic, we've been doing our best to honor what's most important to us: our team of teachers, our families and greater community and our mission to provide the highest quality early childhood education.  

Since the COVID-19 closure started mid-March, we have sung, danced and adventured with over 18,000 smiling faces at free and pay-what-you-can rates.

During the forced closure, Bubbles Academy pivoted overnight to offer virtual classes to the community, launch e-learning for preschool students, and foster a sense of connection and community through technology.

The closure extended weeks and then months past what was expected, and the core team of teaching artists rallied around a Virtual Bubbles Academy. They came up with new classes, new offerings, innovative ways to make virtual classes more engaging, and even built a virtual summer camp from scratch.

We appreciate the way this community has cheered for us and supported us every step of the way. You and your children have kept us going and helped to strengthen our mission.

As we welcome our first small groups of preschool students back in the building and move through limited re-opening phases, we need your help NOW MORE THAN EVER.

To safely operate under the current guidance from DCFS, CDC, and IDPH, we are restricted in what we can offer in person like many other industries. Our preschool classroom capacity is capped lower than our typical classroom size and we are not yet able to offer in-person parent-child classes. However, the fixed costs to operate our space, pay our rent, employ our loving teachers stay the same. The costs to keep everyone safe with the necessary PPE & sanitation procedures continue to rise, while our revenue is at less than 25%.

Bubbles Academy needs to raise $50,000 over the course of this campaign to continue operating safely in our Bucktown space.

We humbly ask that if your family is able, please consider supporting the Bubbles Academy reopening fund with a financial contribution to keep us in our Bucktown space, operating as safely as possible to continue to bring the arts-integrated Bubbles magic you know and love to our community. 

If you are unable to offer financial support, please help us spread the word with a share of this page with your network, or sharing a story about how Bubbles has touched your life. 

Thank you and we can't wait to sing, celebrate and play with you and your little ones!

story:
Jen broke her jaw in 3 places - shattering the right and left side, and sustaining a vertical fracture in her chin.  In addition, she has 5-6 broken teeth, and her jaw was wired shut.  She is out of work for at least a month, and medical bills will be hefty.  She lives alone, with her beloved dog Finn.

Net proceeds will go towards Jen's basic needs, and medical expenses.  

Contributing to this fund will give Jennifer a peace of mind and allow her to keep the independence she has strived so hard for.  Her most immediate need is paying her rent of $565 on June 1st.

Maybe you can't help, but know someone who can.  Please direct them to igg.me/at/JenandFinn

story:
Welcome!

My name is Evelyn Kenney and I am a recent graduate of Azusa Pacific University! I have been so blessed to be able to learn and grow during my three years there and my good friend Megan and I will be leading a group of 7 students to impact the community of Dundalk Ireland this summer!

These funds will go to funding all of the services and projects we will provide and complete during our 5 weeks in Ireland! We will be serving the Birches Alzheimer's community five days a week through care-taking and initiating activities for the center. Alongside this work we will be implementing the programs we developed for all ages of sunday school, youth group, and Vacation Bible School for the surrounding community. 

Please join us in pursuing this call to Ireland as we begin to prepare financially and pray for both the receiving community and our team. We ask for prayers for our safety, health, and cohesion so that we may be God's vessel in any way to reach this community and anyone we come in contact with. Our mission is to share our stories and hear theirs. We will do this in love, acceptance, and hope for the potential in these connections and the furthering of the Kingdom of God!

Please follow our trip on my blog: http://honestlyeve.blogspot.com/

We will share updates and prayer requests as well as many photos and experiences!

Thank you all for taking the time to participate in this mission! Christ is so faithful and we are so excited for what this trip will do both in the lives of the Dundalk community and in each of our hearts. 


Truly,


Evelyn Kenney

story:
What prevents talented entrepreneurs from less visible cultures to promote and affirm themselves in a globalized world? 

Tasuleasa Social has partnered with Synergis Counseling in order to provide young Romanians with training and and mentorship on two issues: 

(1) affirm themselves globally as equal partners and leaders, while keeping a solid connection to their local cultural values and heritage; 

(2) pitch their ideas, knowledge and talent to potential partners and investors around the world. 

The pilot training will take place August 1-10, 2014 in the Carpathian mountains of Transylvania, Romania. It will be followed by online workshops and the creation of a Leadership University, with on site and virtual classes throughout the year. 

Our Top Donors receive FREE PARTICIPATION AT THIS SUMMER TRAINING IN TRANSYLVANIA. 


WHO WE ARE

Tasuleasa Social is a Romanian non-profit organization founded by Alin Useriu-Uhlmann in 2001, with the purpose of creating meaningful impact at a social, environmental and cultural level. 

Synergis Counseling is a partnership between Cosmin Gheorghe and Patricia Rojas-Zambrano (see details bellow). Synergis is located in San Francisco, California and offers counseling, executive coaching and organizational development training.  

ALIN USERIU-UHLMANN: "Dare To Dream!"

Alin is a TEDx speaker and one of the ten Romanians nominalized by Discovery Channel in their Anybody Can Be a Hero campaign.  In 2001, upon his return to Romania after living a few years abroad, Alin found his childhood land undergoing an ecological disaster. He started building Tășuleasa Social, a volunteers' wonderland in Bistrița, Northern Transylvania, with the steady purpose of "changing mentalities and engaging in mindful and meaningful activities".

COSMIN GHEORGHE: "Local Passion, Global Purpose" 

Born and raised in Romania where he graduated as an MD in General Medicine, Cosmin moved in 2000 to California to study psychology. A Huffington Post blogger and enthusiast of global entrepreneurship, Cosmin uses his skills and knowledge of human relationships and communication to coach individuals and organizations in the San Francisco Bay Area and Silicon Valley on issues like global leadership and culture change. 

PATRICIA ROJAS-ZAMBRANO: "Expressive Arts Social for Change" 

Patricia is a native Colombian working in Berkeley and San Francisco, licensed psychotherapist, co-founder of Synergis Counseling (together with Cosmin) and founder of Expressive Arts Social and Art Journaling Workshops. As the Secretary and Executive Leadership Team for International Expressive Arts Therapy Association, Patricia seeks to inspire at a global level in the transformative power of the arts. She provides counseling and training for effective social change. 

WHY IS THIS PROJECT IMPORTANT FOR US AND THE WORLD 

All three of us are born and raised in rather small, often "invisible" cultures, which often have difficulties situating their value and participation in a globalized world. And all three of us have followed our passion and purpose, adventuring outside of our comfort zone to become "global locals". 

We want now to gift further our knowledge and experience. Through Mentorship and Training we will provide precisely this guidance, to those who need it in the moments they need it the most.


PILOT TRAINING (August 1-10, 2014). The training will consist in global leadership interactive seminars (morning-noon, with Cosmin) and expressive arts social processing (after-noons to evenings, with Patricia). Training will be centered around two large themes. 
I. The impact of cultural values on the behavior and decision-making of entrepreneurs and leaders. The seminars will use rigorous academic intercultural research, which has been performed for the past decades in over 90 countries. We will talk about Power and Hierarchy, Uncertainty Avoidance and Social Anxiety, Individualism and Collectivism, Direct or Indirect Communication, and much more. 

II. The interplay between Personal Cultural Identity and Global Identity, and how they are influenced by cultural values, norms and rituals.  

What We Need & What You Get

Alin generously offered Tasuleasa Social facilities. 

Cosmin and Patricia will donate their time and free leadership training, counseling and mentorship. They will also offer a limited number of free counseling and consulting sessions as perks for donors, and will invest time in promoting this campaign to potential donors for the next 60 days. 

Our Global Leadership project is not possible without your contribution. The first group of hopeful 30 young Romanian leaders is waiting for us and for YOU. 

Remember, our top 3 donors will be coming with us for the duration of the camp in the heart and soul of Romania: Bistrița, Transylvania! If you cannot attend this summer, your place will be reserved for any other Synergis-Tasuleasa Social event or training. 

Please see our Donors Perks bellow! We are offering absolute transparency of this project: free accommodation for our top three donors, who are invited to be with us in Transylvania and experience the project first hand!

Other perks include reduced fee counseling, digital video-photo albums, reduced fee personal or executive coaching, and intercultural and organizational consulting, as well as original paintings by Patricia Rojas-Zambrano - we placed the pictures of the paintings here, since there is no picture space in the perks section: 

"SAILORS' ANGEL" - mixed-media 36"x48" (90x120cm)


SHAMAN'S DREAM - acrylic on paper 12"x19" (31x48cm)


MAYA SERPENT - mixed media on bristol paper 18"x24" inches (46x61cm) 


The Impact

Your donation will have a world wide impact, as a result of the global projects developed by young Romanian entrepreneurs. You become a founder of a unique Global Leadership University, of which you and your children could benefit. 

Why trust us that our project will indeed initiate the expected change? Because we have a proven record of accomplishing similar projects. 

Alin's lifetime project is clearly documented: Tasuleasa Social.

Cosmin's global leadership projects range from his latest work with high-tech startups, going back all the way to his work in the 1990s, as a fellow of Soros Foundation for an Open Society. 

Patricia's  proudest accomplishments include her work with the internationally recognized non-profit Opción Colombia, which promotes community development and the strengthening of civil society. 

Should you need more details about these accomplishments, please feel free to contact us or our project partners. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Talk to your friends and family about this project, and send personal emails with links of this project on your social media friends. 
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hello! I'm Rebecca Brown and I'm a Film School Student living in London. In my spare time, I'm a YouTube Vlogger with 200,000 subscribers! I love tackling hard topics and delving into discussions head on, such as Depression, Trichotillomania and now I would like to explore the topic of Compulsive Hoarding.

What is Compulsive Hoarding?

Compulsive hoarding means excessively acquiring items that appear of little or no value and not being able to throw them away, resulting in unmanageable amounts of clutter.

In recent years, shows on hoarding have all focused on middle aged participants. Hoarding is a life long disorder that isn't diagnosed until later life, however it has to start somewhere!

The plan is to document the lives of two young hoarders, myself and another as we explore our possessions. Through this documentary, I'd like to explain what hoarding is to a younger audience.

What We Need & What You Get

To make this documentary a success, it needs your support!

All the funds raised will go towards the project: hiring equipment/crew/travelling costs - it all adds up!

Even if we don't reach our goal, any funds raised will have a major impact on the project! Your input is invaluable!

Risks & Challenges

The subject matter can be upsetting for some and the topic is often misunderstood, however I want to try my best to push against stigma!

Other Ways You Can Help!

Do you like the idea but can't donate? Not to worry!
You can share this page link on social media sites such as Facebook and Twitter will be more than appreciated! Just a simple share can have an impact on this project.

Please spread the word between friends, family and followers!

story:
Overview of Global Glimpse 

Global Glimpse designs and delivers powerful programs that inspire youth from diverse background to (1) further their education, (2) become agents of change in their local communities, and (3) be responsible and successful global citizens for life.  GG's international service learning experiences bring high schools students to the developing world where their programs instill global awareness, social responsibility, leadership skills and deep compassion.  Some statistics:

  • In 2014, Global Glimpse served 600+ students in New York City and Bay Area public high schools and is building for additional expansion in 2015

  • 96% of Global Glimpse alumni are accepted and are currently enrolled in college

  • 86% of Global Glimpse students are independently traveling outside the US for the first time 

  • 57% of these students are low income and 74% are female

Lea's Connection to Global Glimpse

I joined Global Glimpse's Advisory Board near the beginning of 2014 after learning more about their impact, brand and growth trajectory.  Since then, I have become even more proud to be affiliated with this organization.  I am routinely impressed by the caliber of GG's programs and inspired by the students' own words.  As a Board member, I volunteer my time and ideas and meanwhile learn from other Bay Area leaders that are also choosing to help Global Glimpse grow.  It is an exciting exchange. 

Now it is my turn to help raise support for Global Glimpse, with a goal of $600 in December.  Investments in Global Glimpse help empower a next generation of responsible and successful global citizens.  Thank you for considering Global Glimpse as an honorable recipient of your support.

story:
Student Support Services

Student Support Services (SSS) is a learning community for low-income and first-generation college students at Creighton University. It offers academic, social, spiritual, and financial support to students who might otherwise struggle to complete their education.


As tuition rates climb, low-income and first-generation students need additional financial support to be successful. Additionally, SSS needs resources to support its students' academic, personal, and professional growth. Your donation to SSS will help advance its Jesuit mission to positively impact the lives of underserved students. 

SSS provides students with:

  • Access to study spaces & computer labs
  • Community building activities like potluck dinners
  • A family atmosphere
  • Cultural immersion trips
  • Professional workshops
  • Wellness programming
  • Professional tutoring


The Impact

For over three decades, SSS has helped first-generation and low-income students be academically successful at Creighton. SSS students have a higher graduation rate than the university as a whole, and they maintain an average GPA of 3.1. Further, the number of students with a GPA of 3.5 or higher has grown significantly over the past 12 years. Below is a chart that tracks the rising GPAs of SSS students (SP = spring semester, FA = fall semester).


Your donation, no matter how small, will help SSS continue to provide students with the academic, emotional, financial, and spiritual support they need to be successful at Creighton.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation, simply share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and any other social media platform that will reach the Creighton community and beyond.

story:
What is this all about exactly?

Help me keep Playing At Learning afloat  - it does amazing work in inspiring  youth in STEM.  The short of it?  I'm raising $49,000 in 49 days for Playing At Learning, an amazing, all-volunteer nonprofit that benefits our young people and inspires them towards STEM Careers!  I need your help to make it happen!  


In full disclosure (aka the small print) - I co-founded Playing At Learning and am currently the president (as a part-time volunteer) of the nonprofit. I receive NONE of the funds and will never take a salary from Playing At Learning. I have a separate full-time day job that I love.



What We Need & What You Get

How about about warm, fuzzy feelings?     < See cute JrFLL Kids here >

Every dime raised goes straight to Playing At Learning!    


It is simple:

 If you want to change the world, you help young people.    

If you want to make the world a better place, we need to engage young people that want to solve real-world problems AND invent/create a better future,  you need to support local FIRST partners like Playing At Learning!   

Playing At Learning's programs like NorCal FIRST LEGO League are dedicated to reducing the digital divide, particularly with under-represented minorities and girls.   Sparking an interest in math and science is a key to providing economic life choices for our youth.  The focus is on affordable and sustainable  activities related to science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) skills.    

The reality is that all 3 of Playing At Learning's programs (NorCalJrFLL, NorCalFLL, NorCalFTC) are immensely successful and fast growing but that the program partner - Playing At Learning - needs help and more support to help continue that growth.  

  • Did you know that Playing At Learning is the largest all-volunteer FIRST partner?    
  • Did you know that ZERO of the FIRST team registration fees go to Playing At Learning?

This season,  Playing At Learning will serve more than 6,000 K-12 youth and engage more than 3,000 volunteers!  We aim to keep programs as low cost as possible but have to start considering how to fund operations in a sustainable way.

Playing At Learning has been incredibly frugal - but is reaching a tipping point where they need to grow infrastructure and provide better teacher/coach/mentor/team support.  From supporting 7 events in our first year, to 40 in 2012-213 and expected to 60+ this season, means that everything has to be "supersized"  -  the program growth is not slowing down!   This is great news but means new strategies and methods have to be put in place.      

Until last year,  Playing At Learning's entire nonprofit operations were in a donated home office with 3 rented storage lockers - this made it nearly impossible to support tournament partners, provide training or even work days for teams.    Playing At Learning now has  The Play Space - a cool, "makerspace" type of facility for the entire FIRST community to use throughout Northern California!   This includes our "sister program" FIRST Robotics Competition.    < Check out the FULL SIZED FRC field available for FRC teams to use!  >

Being involved in FIRST programs inspire innovation, and foster well-rounded life capabilities including self-confidence, communication, and leadership.   This increases a person's chances of earning a living for herself and changing the world for present and future generations.   FIRST Programs Work and Playing At Learning is the way to best support our youth in / around the Bay Area, Sacramento and throughout Northern California!    

Despite the unbelievable accomplishments in serving youth since 2004 —the organization is in danger of having to cut back on programs or charge a "partner fee" to participate.  We don't really want to do this - so we are looking at creative fundraising ideas.    

I cannot think of a better way to help than to raise $49,000 for an insanely great organization that is helping to change the world in our little corner of the world!


Here's how you can help


First, GIVE YOUR MONEY. (a bit obvious but needed to be said.) 

Thinking of sending me a card or gift for {christmas, birthday, anniversary, insert fav gift giving opportunity here}??    Well, give ten bucks instead.  You'll save some trees  - real or virtual -  and save my waistline and as a bonus, you'll get a super-fun pack of "FIRST themed stickers" available ONLY through this campaign. 

Or give twenty five and get one of the grab bag of "most popular" FIRST-themed buttons.  It's almost as good as a pony!   And the prizes get more awesome with more money!


Equally, or perhaps more importantly, tell all your friends to give us a bit of their money  - And for those that like social activities -  Set up your own campaign to help Playing At Learning!   Seriously: help spread the word! Tweet something hilarious and/or heartfelt (bonus points for doing both in 140 characters).    Leave nice comments!    Forward on Facebook.  

You can share right from the Facebook/Twitter/Google+ buttons below.

You're more creative than I am. But basically, for the 49 days of this campaign, do anything and everything to GET THE WORD OUT THERE.    

Thank you, and LET'S DO THIS THING.


Join Us & Invest in the future!

Donate, Share & Get 5 Friends to do the same


Thanks, Jill

story:
So What's This All About?

About me:

Hi! My name is Carolyn Bonini. I am 18 years old. I was brought up in the Poconos, PA, but now I live in Bridgeport, CT. I just graduated from Bridgeport International Academy (Yay!). 

If you would like to contact me, email me at: carebonini@gmail.com

What I'm doing:

Next year, I will be taking a gap year in Europe. I have been accepted into 2 major programs. The first program I'll attend is called D.O.N.E. (Development of New Environments). It is based off of Slovakia. On this program we will be doing service projects, character education, a mountain challenge, even some self-defense. This program will last approximately 3 months.

After the D.O.N.E. program, I will be WWOOFing. I will stay with a host family and help them tend to their farm in exchange for accomodation and food. I will have this great opportunity to learn about a new culture and meet interesting and eco-friendly people, while learning quite a lot about organic farming.

Where the money goes:

Any contributions made toward my adventures will strictly go toward that specific purpose. All donations are GREATLY appreciated - so greatly appreciated that I offer you my unique and handmade PERKS (look on the right of the campaign). Also if you have any tips or advice for my travels, especially about VISAs, I would love for you to email me (look above). Thanks for all of your help!

 

What I Need, & What You Could Receive!

I have already raised a thousand dollars on my own, which covers the cost of the D.O.N.E program and supplies for the trip, but I still need 2 thousand more to cover part of the costs below.

I need funds for the basics, including:

  • the plane tickets, there & back again...
  • traveling between countries (between programs)
  • emergency cash just in case

Perks!

If you donate, I've got some great perks you could receive. There are handmade friendship bracelets, cards, earrings, even covers of the songs that you love. I have experience selling the earrings I've made, so you know they're legit! As for the music, for those of you who don't know me, I have a lot of experience performing and covering songs.

As for the largest perks, you can receive a book I printed of my travels, or larger bundles. The book will have a lot of pictures and funny stories, along with random adventures that were really meaningful to me, and hopefully will be for you, too. The larger bundles are explained in the descriptions. I will love you forever if you purchase one of them. 

I've also got some randomly awesome perks mixed in, which I virtual pinky promise on doing. I will even take pictures and/or video as evidence that l do them. 

The Impact

This is a HUGE opportunity for me. :) I will be taken completely out of my comfort zone. It is my first step as an independent person. I believe that through this trip, I will gather a stronger understanding on how I want to impact the world. This is a necessary step in order for me to pick the direction I want my life to go.

I have never gone on a trip so far from home, however I have been on more local programs. One example of this was Vision Quest, in which we traveled the Northeast of the U.S. and did some community service projects for the Penobscot Indian Nation. I fundraised for that program as well, and all of the proceeds went toward that trip.

I promise that your funds will be in safe hands, and that I will use them purely for my education and travels in Europe. Thanks so much. :O)

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't sweat it if you can't donate. Getting the word out is just as helpful. It would be awesome if you could share this with your friends and family. There are some share tools on this page that you could use. Thank you, thank you, thank you!!

story:
We are Maya Traditions Foundation, based in Panajachel, Guatemala. Together with Maya Educational Foundation (MEF), we are asking for your help in supporting ten of our brightest students attend university.

In Guatemala, there are more than 6 million indigenous inhabitants (60% of the country’s total population), yet the majority continues to lag behind the non-indigenous population in social statistics: they are 2.8 times poorer and have 13 years less life expectancy. It is estimated that only 5% of university students are indigenous.

We want to change this reality.

The students involved in our Youth Education Program are bright, creative, socially-conscious individuals that hope to contribute positively to their communities and create significant change in Guatemala. We want to provide them with all the support necessary in reaching their highest potential and achieving their dreams.

We currently have 10 students who would like to attend university next year, but because of financial difficulty, they won’t be able to without your help.

Our students have a range of desired interests. Pedro wants to study system engineering. Sucely wants to study business administration. German wants to study medicine. Vicky wants to study social work.

Where will your funds go?

Depending on the desired field of study, university tuition in Guatemala can cost anywhere from $750 to $1,200 a year. This price does not include the costs of commuting to and from school, food, books, printing, or the myriad of other costs associated with attending school. Many of these families struggle to make ends meet and simply cannot afford to send their children to university, when they can be working instead.

Through your donation, you will be directly supporting our students in their efforts to further their education, increase their knowledge, and better their lives as well as that of their families and communities.

We want to raise enough money to support each student with $1,000.00 per year towards their education. And if you help us raise more than $10,000, we will be able to support more than 10 students!

As well as financial support, Maya Traditions Foundation will offer these students’ personal and professional development with workshops throughout the year, tutoring, and ongoing academic guidance and moral support provided by our Programs Coordinator.

The Impact

Having served indigenous children and families for over fifteen years in partnership with Maya Educational Foundation, Maya Traditions, or known locally as Fundación Tradiciones Mayas, is an essential part of the education solution in Guatemala. As our students have reached the age of university, we want to continue to support them in their efforts to further their education.

Benedicto Ixtamer, a long-term scholarship recipient, shares his success in a recent testimonial:

“Fundación Tradiciones Mayas is part of the seed in the formation of a student. Actually, Fundación Tradiciones Mayas is one of the strongest organizations helping indigenous people and students towards a better life. I especially thank you for supporting me in my formation as a student and adult.  I believe that life is built day by day and made step by step. After graduating as an elementary school teacher, it was difficult for me to find work in teaching because in our government system, everything depends on your connections. But my enthusiasm persisted, and I began to devote myself to painting and started to guide tourists to attractive places. In 2004, I eventually came to the United States to exhibit my paintings. After my trip, I rented land to start a language school in my village. We then bought land and began a formal school to teach languages. In 2005, with the support of parents of children with disabilities, we formed a legal NGO for people with disabilities. With my enthusiasm, we have managed to make contacts in the administrative system of education in Guatemala to officially declare us as a Public School for Children with Disabilities.  Every year I continue to travel abroad to exhibit my art, and was most recently in Telluride, Colorado with the arts and advocacy organization Mountainfilm. I have also currently been working on a community garden in my village where people can grow vegetables to better their nutrition and daily diet. None of this would have been possible without the early support and guidance of Fundación Tradiciones Mayas.” 

Through a comprehensive Youth Education Program, Maya Traditions ensures the integral development of our students, working to improve attendance rates of students at all grade levels through economic support that offsets educational expenses, accompanying students in their educational pursuits by offering tutoring and year-round staff support, and contributing to the professional and personal development of young people to become thoughtful, analytical and creative community leaders, as demonstrated in Benedicto Ixtamer’s statement.

Other Ways You Can Help

1.  Like us on Facebook. Our efforts in Guatemala don’t stop here, so keep up to date with what we’re doing and how you can continue to help us empower local indigenous communities.

2.  Spread the word. Share this campaign on Facebook, tweet about it, and email your friends and family. The more people know about this campaign, the more we can create change together.

3.  Purchase Fair Trade products on our website and through Global Crafts which ultimately support the indigenous women and families we work with.

4. Check out our partner Maya Educational Foundation (MEF) who have been avid supporters of our Youth Education Program, allowing us to financially support the students of our artisans for over 10 years.

story:
Earthcoco, Inc. is a coconut products company with corporate offices in Santa Monica, California and based in the Philippines. Even before we created our first product, we launched our first “Tools for Schools” drive to supply basic school supplies to the Omawas Elementary School in East Samar. It is our way of giving back to the community in which we work and live.

 Our second annual "Tools for Schools" drive will include two more elementary schools in our municipality, the Camada and Mina-Anod Elementary Schools, increasing the number of students we are helping from 208 to 628.

 We are hoping to raise $10,000 to supply pencils, pens, notebooks, backpacks, shoes, and computers, as well as soliciting used textbooks, dictionaries, encyclopedias, and atlases from potential donors. This year's drive will include the construction of two new classrooms to accommodate our growing number of students.

 As our program grows, we are partnering with other businesses, charitable organizations, and NGO’s to achieve our goals.

 

 PROJECT COMPONENTS

 

1. Compiling donations, warehousing, and shipping supplies.
2. Scheduling drive dates for recipient schools.
3. Engaging staff & volunteers, banners, tables, transportation, and food.
4. Providing building materials, carpenters, masons, and electricians.

 

Since our first "Tools for Schools" drive last December, we see the happy faces of the children we have helped. While the pencils are getting shorter, the notebooks fuller, and shoes more worn, the impact of this little act of kindness has changed the future for the children of East Samar.

 Please join us at Earthcoco, with your donations large and small, and help us change the future of our planet.

 

Earthcoco. Healing the planet one coconut at a time.
story_txt:
Earthcoco, Inc. is a coconut products company with corporate offices in Santa Monica, California and based in the Philippines. Even before we created our first product, we launched our first “Tools for Schools” drive to supply basic school supplies to the Omawas Elementary School in East Samar. It is our way of giving back to the community in which we work and live.
 Our second annual "Tools for Schools" drive will include two more elementary schools in our municipality, the Camada and Mina-Anod Elementary Schools, increasing the number of students we are helping from 208 to 628.
 We are hoping to raise $10,000 to supply pencils, pens, notebooks, backpacks, shoes, and computers, as well as soliciting used textbooks, dictionaries, encyclopedias, and atlases from potential donors. This year's drive will include the construction of two new classrooms to accommodate our growing number of students. 
 As our program grows, we are partnering with other businesses, charitable organizations, and NGO’s to achieve our goals.
 
 PROJECT COMPONENTS
 
1. Compiling donations, warehousing, and shipping supplies. 2. Scheduling drive dates for recipient schools. 3. Engaging staff & volunteers, banners, tables, transportation, and food. 4. Providing building materials, carpenters, masons, and electricians.
 
Since our first "Tools for Schools" drive last December, we see the happy faces of the children we have helped. While the pencils are getting shorter, the notebooks fuller, and shoes more worn, the impact of this little act of kindness has changed the future for the children of East Samar.
 Please join us at Earthcoco, with your donations large and small, and help us change the future of our planet. 
 
Earthcoco. Healing the planet one coconut at a time.

story:
What is BioSoap 2.0?

Cabot School's project based learning model embraces student-driven ideas that emphasize deep and creative exploration of content. Central to our philosophy is the belief that students learn best when engaged in roles of responsibility and have both voice and control when developing their understanding of our world. Always striving to break away from dry, boring class routines, this semester our biology class is transforming the science lab into a high quality, analytical soapmaking workspace.

In order to create effective, skin-friendly, attractive soap bars, students examine concentrations of biomolecular fats and oils, overall pH levels, and carefully manage the inclusion of source ingredients. We do far more than design, produce, and personally test the soaps ourselves. We also learn to market and package the soaps, perform cost analysis, and run our own crowdsourcing campaign through Indiegogo. 

This year, our goal is just $1000. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal of $1000 covers the basic costs of sourcing ingredients, packaging needs, and shipping. When you invest in our BioSoap project, you will receive high-quality bars of student-produced soap while investing in something bigger - our passion to learn and explore. With your support, we can pioneer new molding techniques, additional ingredients, seek out even more essential oils and unique scents, and realize our wildly creative "what if..." ideas! 

Who knows what will happen when someone makes that first batch (probably ever) of "Amazing Chocolate Lavender Pumpkin Pie" conditioning soap? Wouldn’t you like to find out? Well, with your help, we can! Do you fancy a traditional, well-balanced, artisanal blend, or something more bizarre and unexpected? With your help, we can offer the whole range. With your help, the sky's the limit. 

Stretch Goals

What happens if we exceed our goal? WE KEEP GOING.

We get CRAZY creative: More molds. More colors. More equipment. New Soap Formulae. Extreme ingredients. A beefed up exhibition. Michael has to shave down to some kind of weird haircut. Marketing to the local community and selling our products. A permanent, on-going project for years to come. 

[Waitaminute... Michael has to shave down to some kind of weird haircut?!]

The truth is: if you name it, we've probably dreamed it up in class. You can help us make it possible. If we're nearing the $1000 mark, don't hesitate - donate! Our work will scale with what we can muster, and that translates into amazing new soaps for you and the rest of the community, and a completely unique learning opportunity for our students.

What Happens If We Don't Make Our Goal? 

Our funders will still receive their soaps, but production will be scaled back considerably and we may have to reconsider recipes and a few soaps. We will focus on small quantities and do the best with what we have available. Some soaps will still happen, but our creative vision will have to be refined, and corners will need to be cut.


The Main Attraction: Biosoaps

All of these soaps are still being developed, tested, and reviewed with the intent to bring you the best soap possible. Because funding will allow us to experiment even further with our ideas and possibly continue to add new ideas, a student will contact you at the end of the campaign to select your actual soaps - not during the donation phase. However, you are 100% guaranteed to receive your choices at the end of our process... so keep visiting to see what we're cooking up!

For every soap in production, there is a short description along with a picture of the class working on the creation of the soaps. The soaps are being constantly tweaked to reach their full potential with each bar of finished soap measuring approximately 2" x 2.5" x 1" in size (or of comparable volume in circular forms). The soaps below are just the tip of the iceberg. With your help, we move on to the really crazy stuff!



Floral Explosion:

From the soapmaker: Floral Explosion is a floral soap with notes of Lily of the Valley and subtle notes of magnolia and rose. The soap gently exfoliates with rose petals and is a light pink color. It conditions dry skin and is creamy, so you get the best hand-washing experience. You will be budding with delight! Pun intended.

Ingredients: Palm Oil (30%); Castor Oil (20%); Hemp Oil (20%); Apricot Kernel Oil (10%); Shea Butter (10%); Coconut Oil (10%); Handpicked Rose Petals

Scents: Floral Bouquet; Lily of the Valley; Rose; Lavender; Hyacinth; Lilac; Magnolia Oils



Christmas Blend:

From the soapmaker: This soap will be everything you like about Christmas in a single bar of delicious-smelling soap. Christmas Blend is well balanced in all its properties, and appears as a lovely green, red, and white marbled bar. It cleans well while leaving you smelling wonderful.

Ingredients: Coconut Oil (25%); Vegetable Oil (25%); Palm Oil (25%); Sunflower Oil (25%); Mint Leaves

Scent: Peppermint Oil



Lavender Swirl:

From the soapmaker: Our soap is a creamy mixture of  palm, coconut, and grapeseed oils. This relatively hard bar will be subtly bubbly while cleansing and conditioning to your skin. The final bar of soap will be purple and cream marbled together. It will be lavender scented with a textured top, and free of exfoliants.

Ingredients: Palm Oil (50%); Coconut Oil (25%); Grapeseed Oil (25%)

Scent: Lavender Oil



Holiday Surprise:

From the soapmaker: Holiday Surprise is a beautiful green shimmering round soap with hand selected fresh, local, organic pine needles from Cabot. This soap has a wonderful tea tree and pine scent, and is a great cleanser and is quite sudsy in character! The pure shea butter will leave your skin feeling very soft and conditioned after a nice wash!

Ingredients: Coconut Oil (40%); Shea Butter (20%); Castor Oil (20%); Cocoa Butter (20%); Softened pine needles

Scent: Tea Tree and Pine Oils


Coconut Delight:

From the soapmaker: Coconut Delight is a splendid mix of coconut and chocolate. This soap will leave you feeling cleansed and delighted, with the coconut flakes fused into the soap you will feel like you just finished swimming in the Caribbean. When you’re done using your soap, everybody will be asking you when you got back from your vacation... little will they realize that you’ve just been using some first-rate soap.

Ingredients: Sunflower Oil (40%); Cocoa Butter (30%); Coconut Oil (30%); Coconut shavings

Scents: Coconut and Chocolate Oils



Chock Full O’ Mint:

From the soapmakers: The final soapy product will be minty green with chocolate colored specks. The soap is designed to look and smell like mint chocolate chip ice cream. When exposed to water it will create an excellent minty chocolate scent that will start your day with a bang!

Ingredients: Coconut Oil (35%); Cocoa Butter (35%); Shea Butter (30%); Dried Wild Mint

Scents: Spearmint and Dark Chocolate Oils

Oatmeal Cedarwood

From the soapmakers: Made for those of us who prefer the scent of nature and the outdoors, oatmeal cedarwood leaves skin feeling clean and refreshed while imparting a subtle hint of cedar in the process. The oatmeal combines with other oils to produce a healing skin formula that helps condition your body after a long excursion or chilly winter walk.

Ingredients: Palm Oil (43%); Coconut Oil (32%); Olive Oil (23%); Castor Oil (2%); Steel-cut oats
Scent: Pure Cedarwood Oils


The Frankenbar

From the soapmakers: Back by popular demand and constructed from the amalgamation of soapmaking trimmings during our shaping process, each Frankenbar is completely unique in composition.  After select soap fragments are compiled together into each one-of-a-kind creation, we seal the fragments with pure, moisturizing vegetable glycerin for an unexpected (and often entertaining!) cleansing experience.

Ingredients: Random assortment of above soaps; glycerin

Scent: "Oh, it's its own thing."


The Purist

From the soapmaker: Like your tastes, we'll keep our description simple. A bar of unscented, unadulterated, wonderfully moisturizing soap composed of pure vegetable glycerin. And hey... it's even clear!

Ingredients: Glycerin

Scent: None


So...What Can You Do?

Donate!

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!

Share your excitement with your friends and neighbors!

Get in contact with Michael (mhendrix@cabotschool.org) or other students to find out how you can contribute or possible help funding outside of Indiegogo!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
40 Years of Exceptional Programming 

Founded in 1971, the Washington Youth Garden provides a unique, year-round environmental science and food education program for D.C. youth and their families. Using the garden as a living classroom, the Washington Youth Garden teaches participants to explore their relationships with food and the natural world.

Our Impact

Each year the Washington Youth Garden (WYG) provides hands-on programming quality health and nutrition,  science and environmental education programs for over 4,500 students in the District each year. 

In 2014, our programs engaged students and parents from Wards 5, 6, 7, and 8. 

  • Garden Science: Through our 4 school partners WYG served over 2,000 students and teachers; 
  • Green Ambassadors Program: More than 60 high school students applied for 7 positions in our six-week summer high school internship program; 
  • SPROUT Program: Over 2,100 participants enjoyed the demonstration garden that produced over 900 pounds fruits and vegetables for donation; 
  • Family Garden Day: Over the summer 168 participants planted, harvested, and prepared nutritious recipes from the demonstration garden. 

Invest in the Washington Youth Garden

In 2015, our goal is to expand our garden program to Ward 8 and serve over 5,000 participants.

Your investment in the future of the Washington Youth Garden is essential to sustaining our work. The return on your investment is a healthier, brighter tomorrow for our students, the greater community, the District and beyond as the youth we serve become the scientists, healthy citizens, and environmentalists of the future.


Learn more at www.washingtonyouthgarden.org or visit our Facebook page.

story:
Summary

Cascadia is a choice-based learning cooperative whose goal is to enrich learning and build community for homeschoolers in the Eugene/Springfield area.  Children ages 6-13 can choose from a list of engaging classes, play with other homeschooled children, and learn from a variety of caring adults.  The goal of Cascadia Learning Cooperative is not to take the place of the important work of homeschooling, but to offer supplemental enrichment classes such as in the arts, Spanish, writing, geography, history, and gamewriting.  As a cooperative, parent involvement is central and key to its success, which creates a unique and intimate learning environment.  It is a place for families to learn, grow and build community together!

Research shows that homelearning is possibly the fastest form of education in the United States and also growing in many other nations such as the UK, Australia, Japan and Canada.  There are approximately 2.2 million children homeschooling in the U.S. for a variety of reasons and from a variety of backgrounds.*  Some families have a desire to provide more a non-traditional approach to learning; some families want to individualize the learning environment and studies for each child; some wish to accomplish more academically than they can in a traditional school; and some for religious reasons.  Whatever the reason, homeschooling and unschooling is growing in America, and families are uniting to build their homeschooling communities through social media, email groups, regular playdates and learning cooperatives like ours. 

Learning cooperatives like Cascadia are starting to form all over the country.  They provide socialization for the children, academic and special interest classes, and provide social and educational support for parents.  They are a bridge between traditional schools and homelearning.  They are unique to each community, and community based.

*http://www.nheri.org/research/research-facts-on...

What We Need 

As a new program, the cooperative operates on a very small budget to keep costs affordable for families.  We have started off with the bare minimum, but now that we are up and running, we have so much more that we would like to do!  Our current goal is to purchase some basic equipment that will enhance the ability of our instructors to teach and provide resources and learning opportunities for the children.  Our goal is to purchase:

·  Four laptop computers;

·  Two projectors;

·  One laser copier/printer.

A laser copier/printer is the highest priority because they would serve the basic functioning of the cooperative.  As it stands, teachers are responsible for printing all of their materials off campus at their own expense.  They cannot make any extra copies of materials or spontaneously print something when children’s interests are piqued or the need arises. 

Projectors are our second priority, and could be used in any one of our classes as a teaching tool.  Giving teachers the capability to prepare a lesson/material at home and then project it on the wall with a laptop computer would improve classroom efficiency and allow access to more teaching resources.  Currently, Cascadia does not own or have access to any audio-visual or computer equipment.

Laptop computers are our third priority, and would likely be used in at least half of all classes offered.  Teachers could use laptops in conjunction with a projector or to prepare class materials during a break.  Students would also be able to make use of computers for in-class research, or in certain classes where computer use is required (e.g., video game writing). 

The potential for projector and/or computer use is exciting to Cascadia teachers, as access to this equipment would open the chest of a vast treasure trove of classroom resources.  As one teacher commented,

“I utilize the NASA website as my curriculum.  It is loaded with information for teachers of all grades.  They have great informative videos to go with many of their lessons.  I would love to be able to show these to my class to complement what I am teaching.  They also have great educational games to complement some of their lessons.  I think it would be beneficial to my class to utilize the different technical modalities offered to drive the lesson home to the kids in the all the ways they learn.  We do a LOT of hands on learning, but often the lesson is better learned when presented in different ways, digitally being one of them.”

  ~Ericka Rhodes, Beyond the Sky Teacher

“Clearly the video 'Game Writing’ class could benefit (from access to a laptop computer).  There is at least one kid who couldn't take the class because she didn't have access to a computer.  Others have old computers that don't hold charges and limit our ability to sit at regular seating arrangements and risk tripping hazards on the cords.  The projector would be fantastic because I can't demonstrate on a computer for all to see what to do in the class.  I have to tell them what to do and then go from kid to kid to see if they have it right.  Even for my younger children’s writing class, if I had a projector, I could have prompts and parts of sentences written and projected for them to copy.”

  ~Tina Fredette, Game Writing and Twist and Fold Writing Teacher

“Tomorrow in the ‘Kids Write the News’ class we will interview kids in an alternative school in Costa Rica, and vice versa, using my iPad here and a teacher's laptop there. We tested connections recently and it would be awesome to have a larger screen. I would like to teach a joint biology and ecology class (both schools at same time) this spring, focused on children's forests and forest ecology in both places. A laptop and projector would be very useful!”

  ~Alison Halderman, Kids Write the News Teacher

The Impact

Your contribution would make an impact on the next generation.  There are many ways we can teach our children, and many ways children learn.  While public school works for many children and their families, homeschooling and unschooling is another important learning pathway.  Supporting Cascadia Learning Cooperative will enhance the learning experience, provide options, and create an intimate learning community for homeschooling and unschooling children.  More specifically, these funds will be able to take some of the burden of providing resources off teachers; give children opportunities that they may not have at home; and enhancing the learning experience and widen the learning community for the children.

Challenges

Learning cooperatives like Cascadia are new and untested.  But homeschooling is growing, and it is our belief that places like Cascadia will continue to grow and become valuable assets in communities across the nation. They are opportunities to broaden the scope of education, providing multiple possibilities for different learners at different stages of their lives. 

Cascadia is a cooperative, thus depends on the families that choose to enroll their children to teach classes, supervise playtimes, coordinate social gatherings, fund-raise and more.  But we do have an administrator, Melissa Palma, who has done this before, and done it successfully!  Melissa started and managed a farmers market in Ypsilanti, Michigan and it is in its 9th season. She also started and managed a democratic, free school in Ann Arbor, Michigan, which is in its 5th year.  She is well versed in managing the ups and downs of running a small school and ensuring it is a long term success.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to financially give, please help us spread the campaign by word of mouth, blogging, liking us on facebook, or using the share tools.  Even better, open up discussions in your community about options in educating children!

Laptop computers are our third
priority, and would likely be used in at least half of all classes
offered.  Teachers could use laptops in
conjunction with a projector or to prepare class materials during a break.  Students would also be able to make use of
computers for in-class research, or in certain classes where computer use is
required (e.g., video game writing). 

The potential for projector and/or
computer use is exciting to Cascadia teachers, as access to this equipment
would open the chest of a vast treasure trove of classroom resources.  As one teacher commented,
“I utilize the NASA website as my curriculum.  It is loaded
with information for teachers of all grades.  They have great informative
videos to go with many of their lessons.  I would love to be able to show
these to my class to complement what I am teaching.  They also have great
educational games to complement some of their lessons.  I think it would
be beneficial to my class to utilize the different technical modalities offered
to drive the lesson home to the kids in the all the ways they learn.  We
do a LOT of hands on learning, but often the lesson is better learned when
presented in different ways, digitally being one of them.”
  ~Ericka
Rhodes, Beyond the Sky Teacher
“Clearly the video 'Game Writing’ class could benefit (from access to a laptop computer).
 There is at least one kid who couldn't take the class because she didn't
have access to a computer.  Others have old computers that don't hold
charges and limit our ability to sit at regular seating arrangements and risk
tripping hazards on the cords.  The projector would be fantastic because I
can't demonstrate on a computer for all to see what to do in the class.  I
have to tell them what to do and then go from kid to kid to see if they have it
right.  Even for my younger children’s writing class, if I had a
projector, I could have prompts and parts of sentences written and projected
for them to copy.”
  ~Tina
Fredette, Game Writing and Twist and Fold Writing Teacher
“Tomorrow in the ‘Kids Write
the News’ class we will interview kids in an alternative school in Costa Rica, and
vice versa, using my iPad here and a teacher's laptop there. We tested connections recently and it would be awesome to have a larger screen. I would like
to teach a joint biology and ecology class (both schools at same time) this
spring, focused on children's forests and forest ecology in both places. A laptop
and projector would be very useful!”
  ~Alison
Halderman, Kids Write the News Teacher

The Impact 

Your contribution would make an
impact on the next generation.  There are many ways we can teach our
children, and many ways children learn.  While public school works for
many children and their families, homeschooling and unschooling is another
important learning pathway.  Supporting Cascadia Learning Cooperative will
enhance the learning experience, provide options, and create an intimate
learning community for homeschooling and unschooling children.  More
specifically, these funds will be able to take some of the burden of providing
resources off teachers; give children opportunities that they may not have at
home; and enhancing the learning experience and widen the learning community
for the children.

Challenges 

Learning cooperatives like Cascadia
are new and untested.  But homeschooling
is growing, and it is our belief that places like Cascadia will continue to
grow and become valuable assets in communities across the nation. They are opportunities to broaden the scope of education, providing multiple possibilities for different learners at different stages of their lives. 
Cascadia is a cooperative, thus
depends on the families that choose to enroll their children to teach classes,
supervise playtimes, coordinate social gatherings, fund-raise and more.  But we do have an administrator, Melissa Palma, who has done
this before, and done it successfully!  Melissa started and managed a farmers market in Ypsilanti, Michigan and 
it is in its 9th season. She also started and managed a democratic, free school in Ann Arbor, Michigan, which is in its 5th year.  She is well versed in managing the ups and downs of running a small school and ensuring it is a long term success.

Other Ways You Can Help
 
If you cannot afford to financially
give, please help us spread the campaign by word of mouth, blogging, liking us on facebook, or using the share
tools.  Even better, open up discussions in your community about options in educating children!

story:
Short Summary

Hey Everyone!

Help make this iPad app come to life so that millions of people will improve their social skills, personal presentation skills, and leadership development. They too can find a career or continuing education program that allows them to fulfill their potential, and my app can help. For my cousin who has a developmental disability and for others out there who have trouble with eye contact and public speaking--let's make a difference today by investing in the future.

What We Need & What You Get

All funding will be invested directly to develop "Speech to Text" technology. This software will be embedded in the text displayed on screen to dedect users' vocal intonation, mispronunciations, and timing of their speech. It has a great impact on users' success with the app because the software moniters mispronounciation, vocal intonation, timing of speech, and builds vocabulary.

If you pledge any amount of money under $15 you will get a hand-written HEART-FELT thank you note :) 

If you pledge $15-25 you will get a silicon WRISTBAND

Pledge $50 to $100 and receive an AWESOME T-SHIRT with our logo! 

Pledge $500 or more and receive the APP FOR FREE for the first time when it is released on iTunes, PLUS have your name or company's name published as a "Contributor" on our website!!

If we don't reach our funding goal ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY WE RECEIVE will still go toward the development of the app! So this is RISK-FREE investment! 

The Impact

Eye contact is the most essential skill for successful public presentation. Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorders struggle to make eye contact in their daily lives. Teachers often get nervous during lecture; college students, debate teams, and Mock Trial competitors need to make eye contact with audiences and opponents; CEOs need to make eye contact as keynote speakers or in important meetings. Furthermore, social anxiety prevents many from excelling in public speaking. Our dream is to successfully increase the eye contact skills, pronunciation, and speaking skills of users in one iOS application. 

Long term benefits for users could be: increased high school graduation rates for individuals, leadership development, better interviewing skills for pre-professional or continuing educational opportunities, successful networking opportunities, and stronger interpersonal relationships. 

Your money will directly contribute to the acceleration of the development of our iPad application, and increase awareness of this venture and product. You are enabling the success of our solution to social skills issues. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey if you can't donate PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD! That is just as great! And remember to share this project!! Thank you so much for taking the time to watch our video and contribute to this cause. 

Video shot and edited by Jared Bronen

story:
Short Summary

Hello, I'm Thomas A. Griffin.  I need your help to complete my personal dream.  I want to go back to school and finish earning my college degree.  However, I need your help to overcome the obstacles caused by my physical disabilities.  I have had heart surgery, have a pace maker, and am legally blind in one eye.

Let me explain my situation and background.  In the fall of 1999, I attended Ellsworth Community College in Iowa Falls, Iowa. I did not have any financial aid funding at the time, so I studied hard to raise my GPA so that eventually I would be able to qualify for financial aid. I paid half of my school fees with money saved from work at minimum wage. At the end of my Fall Semester I was successful in raising my GPA, but was running short on funds.  I could not pay the balance of the costs for the Fall Semester and so the school would not let me register for the Spring Semester.  I decided to take time off from school in order to work and save more money to pay for my education costs before returning to school again.  However, things didn't go as planned because after I started working I developed a very serious health problem.

I returned home to South Carolina in December 1999 and searched for full-time employment while working short term temporary assignments. Eventually in November 2000 I was hired in a local B.M.W. Auto Parts Plant (Pierburg, Inc.) as a Production Line Employee for $9.00 an Hour. In March 2001 I was diagnosed with a very bad Cardiac Mitrol-Valve Prolapse that required open heart surgery. The company pushed me out of work onto short term medical leave until my June 15, 2001 surgery date for open heart surgery. On June 25, 2001 I was terminated by certified letter due to my need to be out of work for 90 Days following surgery.  The surgery required my sternum to be sawed in half so that my ribs could be spread apart to allow access to my heart, so it took time for the bone to mend back together and the incisions to heal. 

After the 90 day waiting period, I was unable to find employment and could not get federally funded employment training due to my being fired while on medical leave.  I applied for Social Security Disability, but it was a long, drawn-out process, during which I had no income.  Finally, years later, I was able to obtain my Social Security Disability Benefits.  Because my claim was originally denied, I had to get a lawyer to help me.  When I was finally awarded disability status, I was paid for the years during which I was pursuing the claim, but my lawyer’s fees ate up over a third of that amount. 

My small monthly income from my disability benefits barely covers my basic living expenses, health insurance premium payments, and medical fees.  I pay my parents $250.00 a month to live at their home, and I help to buy food.  I pay physician copays and buy my medications with pharmacy insurance and copays.  Because of having an artificial heart valve, I will have to take blood-thinner medications my entire life.  I had to get a pacemaker installed in March 2011 because I had developed a heart arrhythmia.  My car was repossessed in March 2009 after getting behind on payments.

I'm trying to pay off the remainder of my past college debts so that I will be able to obtain my transcripts, which are being held by the college business office until my debt is paid. I cannot obtain college student loans to help pay future tuition until my college debts are paid in full.  Another important reason I need my transcripts released is so that I can transfer credit hours for classes that I completed in the past, which will allow me to complete my degree much faster and save money.  Once the transcripts are released I can then apply for admission to Ellsworth Community College for a Degree in Business Management or  to Indian Hills Community College for a Degree in Culinary Arts and Entrepreneurship.  Without either degree I have little hope of finding employment or being able to live independently. In South Carolina,  you need to have income that meets or exceeds three times your rent cost to apply for an apartment in a complex.  I can’t meet this requirement without working.

In the spring of 2012 I lost the eye sight in my left eye due to retinal bleeding. Now I am legally blind in my left eye.  If I have any problems with my right eye, I may not be able to drive in the near future, so I need a college degree to help me find employment in a college Town in food service or a hotel in a city setting. I could then ride the city bus  if I live in my own apartment. I must add there is no funding here for disabled adults through vocational rehabilitation. I cannot receive government grant money for school or past school debts. I must rely on student loans and employment on school campus to pay my way to college.  My credit score and income ration will not allow me to obtain a personal loan to pay this debt off. I' m unable to attend college without this campaign goal being met.

What I Need & What You Get

  • I need $ 5,900.00 to pay past college debt so, my transcripts can be released and my student loan application can be approved. Any money raised above this amount will be placed toward tuition and books, plus college deposits. I will pay for my student housing from my government disability income and part time employment.  Getting my transcripts released will also allow me to transfer 40 hours of college credits that I previously earned, saving me time and money in completing my degree.
  • For $1.00 to $14.00 you will have my deep appreciation and I will include you in my thoughts and prayers.
  • For $15.00 to $99.00 you will receive a Signed Thank You Card from me along with a copy of a Picture of a Cross floating in mid air in the sky. This picture is real, the cross was formed by a cloud, and was taken by my friend’s mom during her vacation in Hawaii. It will give you Hope in your Spiritual Quest.
  • For $100.00 or more donation I will give you a Signed Thank You Card from me, a copy of the  before mentioned Picture of a Cross, and a copy of a local or regional Cook Book from the Southern United States.
  • For $250.00 or more you can receive a large canvas print of the before mentioned picture of the Cross in the Sky.  Or you can choose the option to have a custom portrait drawing by an artist (while available).  For samples of his work go to this link.
  • Any Funding obtained will be used to pay my college debts to obtain my college transcripts.

The Impact

 Your help will give me a new lease on my life to encourage others as I overcome my disability to pursue my goal of obtaining a college degree, first at the Associate’s Degree level and later at the Bachelor’s Degree level. Possibly a Master’s Degree if I prove myself worthy. When I had my own automobile I would volunteer during Election Days to help all people to vote their conscience in my county in South Carolina. I was a poll worker who help set up the voting booths with machines. I would answer people’s questions on how to place their personal vote for whoever they wished to win the election of that time. I enjoyed seeing people of this country vote their conscience and heart’  s desire. I miss that time in my life. I have set at home in my bedroom as time passed me by. I now wish to get my college degree and move forward in my life to serve others in my future employment and give service during elections as a member of a local Poll Staff Team.   Also, I don’t mind working and paying my share of taxes when due.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Please spread the word about my goal through Indiegogo Tools and word of mouth, and, possibly Facebook Media or other social networks.  Also, if you cannot contribute, please pray for me to meet or exceed my goal and be able to attend college this Fall 2013.  Remember, it will take a miracle to allow me to return to college this Fall 2013.

story:
04/02/2013:

Thank you so much for your generosity and audience, I am filled with gratitude for what a wonderful journey this has been! While it is the end of my Indiegogo campaign, it is also the start of a much longer journey. Please follow me here: http://byebyestudentloans.wordpress.com/

Much love and Aloha!
Tara

03/22/13:

While my campaign only has 11 more days to go, my quest for financial freedom has evolved into something bigger. Thank you for your generosity and for believing in me! Follow my continued progress here: http://byebyestudentloans.wordpress.com

Love,

Tara

Update:

Our new goal—2%--$3,000

I am feeling so inspired by the support and love I’ve been shown over the past few days. Never did I dream I would meet my original goal (and beyond!) so quickly.

If I can move above and beyond this loan debt it will free me up to give give give!

Thank you for believing in me, please consider a contribution or helping to spread the world to get to us closer to our new goal of paying off 2% of my student loans!

Much love and aloha,

Tara

The Details

My student loan debt total: $105,000

My monthly student loan payment: $800 (Eek!)

Seeking: $1,500 to pay off the total balance of my smallest loan, let’s get that debt-payoff snowball rolling! 

Update 2/20/13: I am feeling so inspired by the support and love I've been shown over the past few days. Never did I dream I would meet my original goal (and beyond!) so quickly. My original goal of paying off 1% of my student loans has now been increased to 2%. Let's raise $3000 so that I can move above and beyond this loan debt and be free to give give give back! 

The Why

I want to continue being able to give back to our local/international communities. Humanitarian work is the reason I became an RN. In addition to being an ER nurse I’m a volunteer nurse (I've volunteered for that big RED organization whose symbol is a CROSS…)

Taking time off to volunteer is difficult with a monthly loan payment that high…tack on the cost of living…but I’m determined to keep giving back. Examples of places I’ve done volunteer work: Kenya (Africa), rural Hawaii and post-hurricane New Orleans.

A great example of how my student loan debt is hindering my service to our local/global communities: late last year and early this year my assistance with Hurricane Sandy was requested THREE times. I was so disappointed that I couldn't go volunteer; taking 3+ weeks off of work to go and help just wasn't financially feasible because of my loan debt. You can imagine how frustrating that was!

The How

The sooner I can pay my loans, the sooner I can pack my bags to go help those in need. I worked hard to get the education and skills necessary to do the work that I do, I want to utilize it to it's full potential. Paying off 1% is a great place to start!

All donations, big and small, near and far, go directly to paying the balance of my student loans. Thank you!! Please help to spread the word <3

~Tara

story:
Soft Skills for a Flat World Online Training Project

Soft Skills are the missing link for many young Indians as they prepare for this new flat world - so this project is to bring them elearning in soft skills - at Indian prices. The project prepares you for the flat world and also takes you instantly to India - even if just through my book which provides a window into how India thinks and operates. By combining the west and India, you can be ready for the flat world.

Your support will help us provide this training free via a charitable foundation for slum children and rural poor, giving them the opportunity of employability and entrepreneurship for improved lives.

You will help us build a sustainable online learning program for today’s flat world and ensure two outcomes - greater western understanding of India and a training program for the 500 million young Indians to be trained.  And through this India project, you might find openings there you never dreamed of. You can join us over there – you can guarantee your spot on our India and the Flat World launch mission including joining us for a master class in Indiai - as we refine this model, reveal the mind of Indian business and open business opportunities for – the flat world. Every single one of you who support us will receive a copy of this book before it is released.

Our rewards are practical – a copy of the book before it is publicly released – access to our online training programs for you and your team, and finally, participation in this India adventure as you join us over there for launch and for a masterclass in leadership and soft skills – in the heart of this flat world –in India.

If all this project does is open your mind to a flat world – and how to align what you say with what you think – already the benefits will be exciting for you – and that excites us. Gandhi said “Be the change you want to see in the world” and this inspires us to deliver this new model of leadership and communication – it is the change we want to see in the world – better communication, tolerance and understanding, values like generosity and patience. This project empowers people to make the most of opportunity – by aligning their soft skills, their attitude and their cross cultural understanding.
