The project prepares you for the flat world and also takes you instantly to India - even if just through my book which provides a window into how India thinks and operates. By combining the west and India, you can be ready for the flat world.
Your support will help us provide this training free via a charitable foundation for slum children and rural poor, giving them the opportunity of employability and entrepreneurship for improved lives.
You will help us build a sustainable online learning program for today’s flat world and ensure two outcomes - greater western understanding of India and a training program for the 500 million young Indians to be trained.  And through this India project, you might find openings there you never dreamed of. You can join us over there – you can guarantee your spot on our India and the Flat World launch mission including joining us for a master class in Indiai - as we refine this model, reveal the mind of Indian business and open business opportunities for – the flat world. Every single one of you who support us will receive a copy of this book before it is released.
Our rewards are practical – a copy of the book before it is publicly released – access to our online training programs for you and your team, and finally, participation in this India adventure as you join us over there for launch and for a masterclass in leadership and soft skills – in the heart of this flat world –in India.
If all this project does is open your mind to a flat world – and how to align what you say with what you think – already the benefits will be exciting for you – and that excites us. Gandhi said “Be the change you want to see in the world” and this inspires us to deliver this new model of leadership and communication – it is the change we want to see in the world – better communication, tolerance and understanding, values like generosity and patience. This project empowers people to make the most of opportunity – by aligning their soft skills, their attitude and their cross cultural understanding.

story:
My name is David Nelson and I live in Raleigh, NC. I am a veteran of the U. S. Army, a Pharmacist and I have been doing martial arts since 1984. In 2004 I published a book about martial arts at my own expense, but it was somewhat of a rough draft. I am currently working on a second edition of the book and my goal is to have a final product that will help a lot of people be more prepared.

With your help I will be able to make a high quality book with a Master Instructor. All money raised will go toward pictures, editing and publishing costs as well as allowing me to donate many copies of the book to young people in Wake County.

We have come up with perks that will allow us to spend time with people and directly interact with our supporters. We know time is valuable to everyone, so we will make it as great and informative as we can.

Our book is designed to help people make informed decisions about martial arts and to help smaller persons defend themselves against larger attackers. Specifically we want to peak interest and guide people toward local martial arts training across the U. S. so they will be prepared. If you cannot afford classes, the book will give you the tools to prepare yourself (please be gentle with friends and family when you practice on them).

We appreciate any help you can give us on this project. If you can pass this along to anyone you think will benefit from fitness, stretching, nutrition, self-defense and martial arts we will be very grateful.

Please check out the perks we are offering, and thank you for your support.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Christopher Kwan and I am fundraising to attend StartingBloc's Institute for Social Innovation! Here's the lowdown on what the program is about!

================
The StartingBloc Fellowship begins with the Institute for Social Innovation.

The Institute is a five-day transformative experience during which young leaders learn to increase their impact, exponentially. The Institute curriculum includes an innovative case-study competition and sessions with industry leaders.

The 2013 Los Angeles Institute will take place February 14 - 18 at the Annenberg Community Beach House in Santa Monica, CA.

================

Any donation is most appreciated. Thank you :) Even if you don't donate, let your friends know! Or spend a couple of minutes checking out Syinc - a nonprofit that I helped in the starting of in Singapore!

story:
Help Israeli and Palestinian bring peace by supporting our annual Israeli-Palestinian Memorial Ceremony.


Combatants for Peace is holding the Israeli-Palestinian Memorial Ceremony in the last 7 years, which has become the largest reconciliation event in the region. 
In order to maintain this most important event this year, and accomodate the anticipated large audiences, we need to raise an amount of 40,000 NIS (~10,000$) - to cover the associated costs.*

The event has become increasingly important for victims from both sides of the conflict as well as for the wider public who wish to acknowledge each other’s grievances and promote a dialogue of peace. 
The ceremony boldly touches on the exposed nerves of the Israeli - Palestinian conflict and brings together bereaved family members from both sides who call together for the ending of the conflict using nonviolent means. 
The ceremony is also attended by artists, public figures and prominent intellectuals, who believe that on such a significant day for the Israeli society we should be reminded that it is possible to create a different reality. 
The ceremony is designed and produced by the Combatants for Peace movement which relies entirely on donations, activists and volunteers to carry out its actions including this ceremony. The number of people attending this event increases every year and last year attended the event around 2000 people. 
We are relying on the generosity of individuals like yourself and we kindly ask you to help us make this important event happen again this year.


You can find more information about the ceremony in this video

How can you contribute?

1. Donations can be easily and safely made through this link.
Any amount will be helpful

2. Please help us to reach out to as many people as possible

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Kylia Whitehead and I am the CEO/Founder of V.O.I.C.E youth program.
  • V.O.I.C.E stands for (Violence Overwhelms Innocent Children Everywhere). Our mission is to decrease the violence amongst our youth by providing an outlet where they can be heard through the arts/entertainment, hopefully decreasing the violence in the streets. 
  • If we were to raise enough money, we can and will be able to create more afterschool programs beginning with the city of Philadelphia with the hopes of expanding international.  


  • With $30,000 we would be able to provide awareness about the program in a creative way by hosting city wide talent shows, play productions, and community service.
  • We will offer a creative outlet for the youth to express themselves, exposure, provide real life opportunities such as building self confidence, communication/social skills, and educational opportunities.
  • If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will be held in the companies account until the goal is met.

The Impact

  • By contributing to Voice youth program, you are giving a child an opportunity to potentially find their passion and purpose in life.
  • ON August 17, 2013 we put together a youth fundraiser concert.  On August 22, 2013 -August 25, 2013, we put on a stage play titled "The Chosen Voice" as an extension of the organization giving the community a visual of what we have to offer.
  • Voice will be a safe haven and a positive place where children can freely express themselves.

Other Ways You Can Help


  • If you are unable to make a monetary donation, thats ok!  You can contribute by spreading the word to your family and friends via social media, Volunteer for future projects, and be apart of our mailing list.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Who we are

Khari and I are two college students that will be studying abroad in Barcelona, Spain this summer. We decided to make our studying abroad experience a project where we could use some of the tools that we are learning in college to empower students with disabilities.

Studying abroad has always been an aspiration of mine, and when I broke my neck in a diving accident I thought my chances of traveling and studying abroad were over. Nevertheless, my sophomore year in college I decided to aim for the unthinkable and attended a Study Abroad Fair. There I learned that my dream to travel and study abroad is in fact possible. Unfortunately, there just isn’t enough support and motivation for students with disabilities to study abroad. After much planning, Khari and I decided to work together to change this. Through Empower On, we hope to encourage other students with disabilities to follow their dreams and make the unthinkable possible! 

We have the incredible opportunity to make a short film about studying abroad with a disability, and develop a program to help students with disabilities study abroad. This will change our lives by helping us learn, grow and reach our goals. However, we also hope to inspire others in our local and global community. With your support we can help empower students with disabilities!

  1. The first stage our of project has already begun in Los Angeles, and includes meeting with our advisors, doing physical therapy, spreading the word, working on the film, and making travel preparations. (Check out our Facebook for updates!)
  2. In the summer we will travel to Barcelona, Spain, where we will study abroad, and do a creative research project, documenting our experience and creating a short film about studying abroad with a disability.
  3. Next we will return to Los Angeles and finish editing our film. Then, we will work with non-profits to do a series of workshops, sharing our film and experience to help other students with disabilities study abroad.
  4. Finally, we will establish a scholarship to help empower students with disabilities to study abroad. 

What We Need 

To continue this project, we need to raise $8,250! If we reach our campaign goal, we will use the funds for:

  1. Study abroad fees
    • $4,500 will go towards paying the rest of our study abroad fees so we can travel to Spain where we will be making our film.
  2. Film equipment
    • $1,500 will go towards film equipment so we have the essential tools needed for the project.
  3. Workshop materials
    • $250 will go towards funding the workshops and creating handouts and other materials to give to students.
  4. Scholarship fund
    • $2,000 will be donated as scholarships for students with disabilities at Cal State LA and UC Irvine, to help empower them to study abroad. We would like to raise enough funds to provide at least one scholarship at each of our universities, with the hope that with more support this could grow into something that we could do annually, and on more campuses.

If we do not reach our entire goal by the deadline, we will still use the funds to complete our project as best we can.

What You Get

We're offering some great perks for your support! (Photos coming very soon) 

  • Digital Scrapbook Download
  • Signed, Limited Edition Poster
  • Limited Edition Tee
  • One of a kind postcard from Barcelona, Spain
  • Personalized Thank You Video
  • Become a sponsor

Other Ways You Can Help

  1. Help us share our story by spreading the word to family and friends! Share our project with anyone who might be interested!
  2. Like us on Facebook!

Thank You!

We're so grateful for your generous support! Thank you for helping us share our story, reach our goals, and empower students with disabilities!

story:
My name is Jeremy Nettifee, and I'd like to introduce you to a friend of mine, Kayley Shade.

Kayley has Spinal Muscular Atrophy type II (SMA).  It is a disease that slowly deteriorates your muscles.  This means that Kayley has limited mobility, has never walked or crawled.  A common cold easily turns into pneumonia, which results in long hospitalizations. 

She has a need for transportation to doctors’ appointments and the hospital, school, normal social activities, and vacations.  Her current van, "Old Blue" has seen better days.  It is rusting out, has leaks, a questionable lift, and mechanical issues.  Because of this, her outings are often limited or impossible, and for essential appointments only.

What We Need & What You Get

What do we want to help Kayley get?

  • Kayley has found a van, a 2003 Chrysler Town & Country with a power ramp and tie downs.  This new van has very low miles, unlike Blue which has 200,000 miles, and should last Kayley a very long time!  She is hoping to purchase this van next week, so we have a very short time to meet our goal!

The Impact

The impact of your contribution would greatly help Kayley with mobility problems with her current van.  A new van would greatly improve her ability to get to doctors’ appointments, family events, and school. 

Kayley has made a huge impact on her community and those around her.  Recently, she entered a contest to win a new van and the sheer number of votes (almost 18,000 in a community of only 2,000!) shows the far-reaching and immense impact Kayley has had on her community.  The local news station has even done stories about Kayley.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes you just simply can't donate; here are some other ways to help Kayley out:

  • SPREAD THE WORD!  Use Indiegogo share tools and let everyone know about this!  Use Facebook and Twitter to share it with all your friends!
  • Maybe you and a few friends wants to get together and help out, every little bit helps!

 

Thank you for helping out Team Shade!!

-Jeremy Nettifee

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
In September, I plan to make the trip from Chicago to London to undertake the Dance Science postgraduate program at Trinity Laban. Always interested in the body, I found recent inspiration from assisting a ballet class for students with cerebral palsy. This introduced me to how I could take my passion for dance to give back to the community. Although the healing process may take longer, the therapeutic and rehabilitative uses of dance dives deeper into the core of the problem. By studying dance science, I would like to research the impact of dance on specific populations beyond the trained dancer. Attending Trinity Laban will help me in this process. Dance does more for the world aside from the creation and performance of art; mind and body both profit from the exploration of this scientific aspect.

Continuing my education in dance science further expands upon my Bachelor of Arts degree in dance. During my four years at Columbia College Chicago, my classes only skimmed the surface of anatomy and kinesiology as it applies to the dancer. Technique classes fostered the discovery of the body’s functionality of movement through somatic exercises. My eclectic training at Columbia introduced me to kinesthetic approaches that stirred a desire to someday study physical therapy. Until recently, dance and science existed as separate entities in my mind. Trinity Laban grants me the best of both worlds, fusing dance and science to create a new path for my passions. Acknowledging other approaches for a healthy body emphasizes the need to support a foundation for a new era of dance and science combined. An education abroad in dance science provides me an opportunity to set this foundation by experiencing a community already embracing this combination.

In my studies, this would be my first step towards developing rehabilitative practice based in dance to support dancers and non-dancers alike. Upon returning from London, I hope to establish a class open to those desiring to work past a lingering injury or any physical limitation, as well as those simply wishing to improve their overall physical health. Working with my students, I plan to use my newly gained knowledge to continue investigating dance’s countless benefits and develop a focused approach to a healthful kinesthetic practice.

            A program such as this does not exist in the states. I am at the point in my career where I need to take risks to build myself as a dancer. Sometimes those risks take you places far from home to learn new knowledge and gain invaluable experiences. Trinity Laban would give me an edge upon returning to my community. An edge advancing the field dance science. Going abroad to continue my studies provides me the opportunity to bring over new approaches to alternative forms of medicine that can contribute towards a healthier America. With the next chapter of my life beginning, I wish to not follow the path laid out before me. Instead, I wish to build my path one step at time, never ceasing to learn something new about what can be discovered from this form. To go abroad and study at Trinity Laban, I am more than certain that I can achieve this level. However, I must be realistic financially. I cannot do this alone. Your help is greatly appreciated and gets me one step closer to making my dreams come true. Every penny helps to pay for tuition, books, school supplies, housing and living costs. If you can't donate, please help me to spread the word about my fundraiser. Many thanks to you all!

 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YUGD1J9Ywdw

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q51r4j1q8WE

story:
Short Summary

Summer is supposed to be a fun time of the year for kids: playing outside, going to special places, eating new things, reading what you want and enjoying the long days. Unfortunately not all youth have can afford to attend quality summer camps, to take vacation trips, to buy the freshest summer fruit or feel safe walking to neighborhood treasures like the parks, playgrounds or local libraries. 

Each summer Mo' MAGIC hosts a series of community activities and projects, focused on helping youth have busy and memorable summers. 

The summer is a critical time for many youth, not having access to the free lunch program at school; lacking a safe place to play, compunded by the fact that summer learning loss contributes to the academic achievement gap.

Help us provide super summer days:

  • Special snacks and lunches for hundreds of youth
  • Distribution of hundreds of books 
  • Safe, fun and supervised learning opportunities that keep youth physically active and mentally engaged. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • $25 donation helps purchase books and we send you a post card from one of the summer youth experiences 
  • $100 provides a special lunch for 10 youth and we send you summer swag: either a t-shirt or one of the titles the youth receieve 
  • $500 provides supplies and materials for a special art project 
  • $1000 provides a full day of transportation for 60 children and youth outside of San Francisco.

The Impact

This is about helping make memories of a super summer. Without your support children and youth suffer in many ways. Understand that your support helps:

  • Children and youth go back to school prepared- mentally, physically and academically. 
  • Provides over 2,000 meals
  • Provides 2,000 books and resources (teachers, lessons, activities)
  • Avoid the call to mischeif, by offering alternative positive opportunities

Other Ways You Can Help

Summer can be a dangerous time for youth, those with no place to go often find themselves involved in negative behaviors. We have lots of ways for you to plug in:

  • Help us get the word out to others
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer at one of our many events

story:
IT'S NOT OVER!!!!!
we're still working towards our goal! Find our extended campaign here:

 http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/summer-litera...

 

 

 

Is ka warran! ("Welcome" in Somali)

Do you believe in the power of education? Do you believe that reading enriches every child’s life?

Our students need your support.

For eight years, our community’s children have thrived in the acclaimed summer reading program at Providence Glen, where they work hard, have fun, and are ready to succeed when school starts again. Now, we need your help to keep the series going.

Our students belong to Somali refugee and immigrant families, and we believe they deserve a safe, fun place to learn and grow.

We’re already halfway to our fundraising goal of $9,500 thanks to an outpouring of donations from the Providence Glen community, including Praxia Partners, Dayspring Christian Community Development Corporation (a faith based nonprofit), and our other development and management groups.

We still have a little ways to go, though, before our July 14 deadline.

The summer program is run by ESL Afterschool Communities, and it focuses on literacy, vocabulary, and instilling a love of reading— but it also does so much more. Children go on field trips to explore our city, enjoy free meals, gain confidence in their problem-solving skills, and engage their families in their academic progress.

Don’t take it from us, here’s what the children have to say!

  • Abdulazeez, age 8, explained, "There are a lot of fun activities here and a lot of reading, so when I go to 4th grade I will be better at reading." Without the summer program, he said, "I would probably just be watching TV."
  • Fardowsa, 9, said, "I like coming because we learn new words and go on field trips."
  • When asked to describe her summer without ESL Afterschool Communities, Hoda, 9, said simply, “It would be boring."

The summer reading series is:

  • Effective. In the 2012 summer program, 100% of our students maintained or improved their reading level. Without the summer reading program, students are vulnerable to "summer slide," the learning loss that occurs over the long break from school.
  • Trusted. ESL Afterschool Communities is a celebrated, popular community outreach initiative that has served Providence Glen since 2005.
  • Unique. Without the summer reading series, families and children will be left with no summer educational opportunities at Providence Glen!

Who Are You Helping?

The ESL Afterschool Communities (ESLAsc) Program at Providence Glen Apartments in Columbus Ohio serves the large immigrant and refugee population in our city. The year-round educational program engages over 30 families to promote learning, encourage community engagement and provide helpful resources to the families here at Providence Glen. Ultimately, the program engages the immediate neighborhood in protecting the welfare of our students, while at the same time engaging our children in our community and giving them a sense of belonging and interconnectedness. 

We really want to set these kids up for a successful school year and give them the tools they need to find their love of reading. It is so important for the children of this community to have engaging and safe activities to do during the summer.

-- Brianne Manczak, educator and program coordinator at Providence Glen

How You Can Help

Maybe $5000 seems like a small amount for such an involved program-- but the impact that amount will have on our students' education is monumental.

Because Dayspring, a 501(c)(3), is running this campaign, all money donated to keep the summer term running is tax-deductible!  All funds exceeding our goal (or if we don't reach our goal, all funds raised) will go toward the Afterschool program for the 2013-2014 school year. 

Whatever you are able to give- $10, $50, or $200-- we promise it will make an impact for our students, their families, and our community.

Donating money isn’t the only way to support our students!

  • Please share this campaign and our story with your friends and family can really make a difference. Help us make some noise about our campaign!  
  • Post about us on Facebook, tweet about us, forward our campaign on to all of your friends, use any of the share features on this page and help us get the word out.
  • Like and share our facebook page.
  • Use the hashtag #savesummerliteracyPG so we can find your shout outs and thank you for your help! Our twitter-friendly address is: http://igg.me/p/450986/twtr/849822

The 6-week summer program serves over 30 children, and requires $9,000 to cover materials, supplies, educator stipends, and two field trips. Praxia  Partners is starting our campaign off with a matching grant of $4,500 to keep the program open for the first session today- but we need your help to keep it open for the second session, which starts on July 15th.

Your Impact

Impressive outcomes from the full school year and summer session really illustrate the impact of the ESLAsC program: 

  • 47% of students increased their Ohio Test of English Language Acquisition (OTELA) scores
  • 29% increased their Ohio Achievement Assessments scores (36% scored proficient or higher in both math and reading!)
  • 94% increased their reading levels
  • 48% increased reading grades/GPA
  • 49% increased math grades/GPA 

Let's not close the book on our summer reading! 

We are so grateful to everyone who is helping us keep this program, and we look forward to helping empower many more kids in the future.

Mahadsanid! ("Thank You" in Somali)

 

About ESL Afterschool Communities

ESL Afterschool Communities (ESLAsC) is an acclaimed outreach initiative of Columbus State Community College’s Center for Workforce Development. ESLAsC serves the city's large immigrant and refugee population by providing a safe, caring environment where children develop academic, social, and personal skills that last a lifetime. Providence Glen is one of three ESLAsC sites in Columbus. Each is located within an apartment complex, encouraging a sense of community and eliminating the need for transportation. For more information, visit http://www.cscc.edu/workforce/eslas.

About Praxia Partners

Praxia Partners is a Columbus-based sustainable development firm. Through its Bridge Program, Praxia Partners seeks to buoy organizations and programs that advance community-building. For more information, visit www.praxia-partners.com 

About Dayspring Christian Community Development Corporation 

Dayspring serves as a catalyst to promote vision, purpose and community action through the development of leadership at the neighborhood level.They provide affordable housing to low and moderate income households and promote economic self sufficiency. Thier services include financial literacy, entrepreneurship, small business development and affordable housing. For more information, visit http://www.rhemachristiancenter.com/dayspring.html

Please share this campaign and our story with your friends and family can really make a difference. Help us make some noise about our campaign!  

Post about us on Facebook, tweet about us, forward our campaign on to all of your friends, use any of the share features on this page and help us get the word out.

Like and share our facebook page.

story:
Cash Match Opportunity:

We have a private donor who has pledged to make a cash match donation of $6,000 if we can raise $6,000 from supporters like you. This means our donor, who is anonymous for now, will match your donation Dollar per Dollar!

This is a huge opportunity for us! Please help us take advantage of it! 

The money raised will help fulfill operating costs for our after school program services for children between the ages of 8 and 13.  We hope to serve kids between the ages of 14 and 18 beginning in August 2013. 

In-Kind Donations:

We are also in need to one to two 12-Passenger vans so that we can transport kids from school to our facility so that they can participate in our after school program.  

We also accept donations of other goods that we can sell to raise money for the foundation. 

You can find out more about our foundation and program by visiting our website: www.skate4homies.org or find us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 

Who We Are:

Skate 4 Homies was founded in 2010. Our mission is to support, preserve and promote skateboarding as a healthy sport, culture and lifestyle for disadvantaged youth.  Skate 4 Homies provides new and refurbished skateboarding equipment, helmets and clothing, as well as educational and art programs to youth in financially challenged households. 

What We Do:

In 2011, we provided skateboarding equipment and educational classes to over 400 local youth. With our support and the positive environment we provide, we help youth build confidence through skateboarding. That same confidence breeds success that translates to other areas of their lives and community. 

Skate 4 Homies is more than just skateboarding. This year we are expanding our educational program to include lessons in the following:

- Art

- Homework Class

- Health & Nutrition

- Math/Science

- Construction/Maintenance 

- Fiscal Responsibliity

- Community Service 

With our youthful approach, these diverse classes help keep kids interested in learning. When students are inspired they will stay in school longer, go on to receive a higher education, and in the end will be better equipped to positively contribute to our community.

Our kids are required to participate in community service projects during the year. For example, last year we cleaned up miles of trash along the Jordan River Parkway and raised over 1,500 pounds of food for the Utah Food Bank. Through community service and mentoring, our kids will continue giving back to their community even after they graduate from our program.

Our Facility:

As with any sport, skateboarding can be dangerous if not done right. That’s why we have a private facility off the corner of 700 South and 300 West, where we train the kids in our program. We are able to build features that meet their skill level. We provide one-on-one training and coaching in a controlled environment. We make sure the kids are wearing the proper attire and using proper equipment.

We cannot provide this level of educational programming without the support of people and companies like you.

story:
Short Summary

The University of Medicine & Dentistry of New Jersey (UMDNJ) with Robert Wood Johnson Medical School is offering an elective course for medical students, residents and other health professionals.  In conjunction with Spring Reins of Hope (SROH) - an EAGALA model program in NJ - we have created a course, The Horse Medicine Wheel / Horses for Healers whereupon medical professionals / students learn impeccable bedside manner from horses!
 
"Horses for Healers" is being offered for the second time as an elective in Spring 2013 through UMDNJ at the SROH location in central NJ.  The class is a 2 week elective where upon two consecutive Mondays are full days spent at the farm with the horses (consisting of a mixture of short classroom lectures and the majority of day spent in the arena/paddock with horses). The following Tues-Fri segment of the course is held on the UMDNJ campus with lecture, lab, shadowing rounds and other classes pertaining to bedside manner within the university setting.
 
This EAL workshop is a new modality and approach, but with very promising results and reactions. See our additional files posted on this campaign where you can read the student evaluations from the first pilot class in April 2012 (PDF in the GALLERY tab of this campaign). The majority response was that this class should be mandatory to graduate medical school! As more students demonstrate similar responses/reactions and results, the closer this will become an accepted model at the interface of basic science and clinical training.  In order to run more courses for more students there needs to be support in paying the costs of the EAL component (insurance, facilitators, horses, facility, etc).  UMDNJ and SROH are seeking support from the community to as a way to cover the cost of this course.

For more information there is also a podcast available and picture slideshow at: http://seen-heard.com/blog/?p=1238
 
 
 
 

What We Need & Why
(The Academia Hump to Get Over)

 

While we believe that improving bedside manner is a necessary part of medical education this course is not mandatory and therefore not funded by the university. Our hope is that by documenting the the positive changes that this course will be implemented as a part of mandatory core curriculum, and will be funded. Until then we need outside support to be able to offer this valuable and long lasting training available to young doctors who are embarking on their medical career.  In April 2012 Spring Reins of Hope partnered with UMDNJ and offered the course free of charge in order to gauge the interest / feedback / and engagement.   After completing the course, both students and administrators from UMDNJ applauded the impact that the horses had on students in the way of experiential learning and illustrating just how subtle body language can be to allow a patient to feel Safe - or - UN-safe. UMDNJ is exploring the viability around establishing this elective course into mandatory training required by M3 and M4 medical students to complete their training (maybe even eventually dental students, nurses, med techs, etc).

*To read student evaluations from the pilot April 2012 course - see the pdf file "Student Evals 2012" loaded in the GALLERY tab of this campaign.

However, this is a new modality (especially to the North-east USA) and getting a new class to be approved and also funded within academia is a large chore. There will need to be more proof! SROH would like to continue offering this course to young doctors in order to help ensure that future patients will meet up with trust and safety within their own healthcare provider network, right off the bat.  We believe that when a patient feels safe and secure (trusts) their health care provider and the decisions he/she makes on their behalf that there is an improved rapport right from the start. This trust and rapport will translate into the treatment plan, increased optimism, higher efforts to follow instructions, and possibly lower Mal-practice claims.

Each Mondays full day session has real costs associated with it running at approximately $1100 for each day. 2-3 facilitators, 4-8 horses, ring fees, facility fees, catering, insurance, etc. all adds up. Two full days at 1100 = $2,200. Indiegogo charges fees for this campaign fund-raising option.  If the entire goal is not met, SROH has agreed to run the course on whatever amount is raised applied to April 2013 class. We are hoping it will not end up costing the equine program money to provide this service. If the amount raised exceeds the total needed, any excess funds will be applied to the costs of the next Horses For Healers session (either Fall 2013 or Spring 2014).

 

  

 

The Impact (Why Does This Training Matter?)

 

The Horses for Healers workshop is an EAL (equine assisted learning) program that allows Medical Professionals (and students) to learn body language awareness and improve upon bedside manner. Horses are extremely sensitive to body language / intent vs. action which makes them superb barometers to gauge and to mirror back the congruency of our body language signals. Over time our big picture goal is to create a positive impact for medical professionals to have fantastic bedside manner, creating a different patient experience, relationship and rapport with their health care providers. Our short term goal is to provide 10-12 medical students in New Jersey with these skills to take with them into their practice and career right from the beginning. So in essence we believe that by funding and providing this one class - it will make a difference to the patients that these soon to be doctors will face in their practice. Its a start!


"Doctors would be far more respectful of their body language and bedside manners if their patients all weighed 1200 pounds; horses help medical students and professionals learn non-verbal communication skills demonstrating the powerful voice of our body's language".
~ Dr. Allan Hamilton, MD, FACS
From Barnside to Bedside; How Horses Teach Doctors the Secrets of Better Bedside Manner1(Course curriculum in over a dozen universities around the world)

 

The Horse Medicine Wheel ~ Horses for Healers:

75% of patients complain that their medical providers do not communicate well...2

How is your bedside manner?

High GPA, but low Press-Ganey survey scores?

Are you and your patients communicating clearly?

The Horse Medicine Wheel/Horses for Healers is a workshop specifically designed for healthcare professionals such as; doctors, dentists, nurses and clinical health science students, house staff, or other healthcare professionals--anyone with direct patient care responsibility. Because health science education stresses intellectual excellence, much less attention is placed on proficient communication, both verbal and non-verbal. Good communication can help increase patient satisfaction, therapeutic outcomes, and malpractice prevention to name a few [Stanford Medicine & Horsemanship, Kane, 2007].3

 

 

Learning to communicate with horses requires an appreciation for all the messages we send and receive as it demands patience, gentleness, self-confidence, sensitivity, focus and a keen awareness. Horses are large but also easily frightened - their survival as prey animals depends upon them being finely tuned to body language, emotional tone and to the position or movement of objects and other beings within their sensory fields. Through this work, medical professionals are able to increase their sensitivity to non-verbal awareness and communication as they explore the poise and self control to interact with a 1000 lb being, their ability to monitor and read the body language of their human patients becomes more refined.

By reflecting back to us the most subtle signals of our intent (that we may not be conscious of) the horses can teach us to be much more aware of the messages that we convey. Horses also can help us refine our instinctual, intuitive and sensory faculties that may have dulled due to pressure of exams/schooling, scientific reasoning, logical diagnosis, and clinical decision making. Horses can challenge us to overcome our fears/indecision and develop confidence, courage and conviction.

 

 

Horses also help medical professionals in that they remain true to their essence - they each have distinct personalities and moods - an approach that works with one horse may not work with another (much like human patients), we therefore have to find other ways to communicate, and generate respect within that relationship in order for it to be based on compassion and trust. Because horses react to the subtlest of our human signals, it is as if they are holding up a magnifying glass to our styles and behaviors. It is in this mirror that we can see our truest image and a path to professional development and growth.

Spring Reins of Hope has customized exercises for UMDNJ students to easily learn:

    • Improved rapport and communication with patients
    • Enhanced bedside manner and an improved understanding of non-verbal messages
    • Confidence building and more refined awareness of self presence
    • Management stress of time constraints with patients and maintain valued rapport

    

  • Why congruency / consistency are desirable for patient relations
  • A developed "Leave it at the Gate" mentality and non-intimidating ways to interact
  • About defined appropriate personal space and boundary setting techniques
  • Strategies for effectively managing challenging clinical situations with poise and self-control
  • Identified patterns of interaction, the reactions elicited by the horses and how that relates to both professional and personal identity
  • See the Emmy Winning NBC 11 News Coverage of Dr. Beverley Kane's Medicine and Horsemanship program at Stanford University
  • Resources on Professional Training and Development with Horses

 

1Allan Hamilton, MD, FACS, The Doctor Who Whispers to Horses at http://www.allanhamilton.com/equine.html2 [Moore et al., West J Med. 2000 October; 173(4): 244-250.]
3The Horse Medicine Wheel workshop is based on the development and proven success of The Stanford Medicine & Horsemanship program at Stanford University, California, developed by Beverley Kane, MD at http://www.horsensei.com/#app=programs_medicine_horsemanship and http://med.stanford.edu/blogs/mandh/

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you are interested in this idea but cannot contribute at this time...would you be willing to help us in other ways?

  • Please share this campaign on FB, Twitter, to your friends, family, maybe even to your doctor?
  • Do you have any contacts or connections to Doctors, Patient Care Advocates, Patient Relations Managers at Hospitals / Clinics? Those connections may have an invested interest in seeing ways to improve bedside manner and therefore may offer some (even if small) support to this idea...
  • Offer any ideas you may have to help raise money - a local bake sale, kitty jar, etc. Little bits do really add up! We may not have thought of everything, and we are all ears...

 

DONATIONS ARE NOT TAX DEDUCTIBLE!
SROH IS AN LLC AND THEREFORE UNABLE TO PROVIDE TAX RECEIPTS. These donations are as a gift to up and coming medical students at UMDNJ to acquire the skills for patient communication and rapport, which will ultimately benefit society and community.

 

Horses For Healers Facilitators:

Maria Katsamanis, PsyD - Clinical Assistant Professor, Department of Psychiatry/Robert Wood Johnson Medical School. Horses for Healers Workshop founder, EAGALA Mental Health Professional & Equine Specialist

Christianna Capra "CC" - CEO Spring Reins of Hope, EAGALA Equine Specialist

(Photos by: Dr. Shari Silverman, VMD of Simply Sound Horse, NJ)
(Video by: Lynn Appel and Cheryl Galante, short edit by BlueRock, NJ)
(Podcast by: Doris J. Gilman, Health Thought Leadership One-to-One)
story_txt:
Short Summary
The University of Medicine & Dentistry of New Jersey (UMDNJ) with Robert Wood Johnson Medical School is offering an elective course for medical students, residents and other health professionals.  In conjunction with Spring Reins of Hope (SROH) - an EAGALA model program in NJ - we have created a course, The Horse Medicine Wheel / Horses for Healers whereupon medical professionals / students learn impeccable bedside manner from horses! 
 
"Horses for Healers" is being offered for the second time as an elective in Spring 2013 through UMDNJ at the SROH location in central NJ.  The class is a 2 week elective where upon two consecutive Mondays are full days spent at the farm with the horses (consisting of a mixture of short classroom lectures and the majority of day spent in the arena/paddock with horses). The following Tues-Fri segment of the course is held on the UMDNJ campus with lecture, lab, shadowing rounds and other classes pertaining to bedside manner within the university setting. 
 
This EAL workshop is a new modality and approach, but with very promising results and reactions. See our additional files posted on this campaign where you can read the student evaluations from the first pilot class in April 2012 (PDF in the GALLERY tab of this campaign). The majority response was that this class should be mandatory to graduate medical school! As more students demonstrate similar responses/reactions and results, the closer this will become an accepted model at the interface of basic science and clinical training.  In order to run more courses for more students there needs to be support in paying the costs of the EAL component (insurance, facilitators, horses, facility, etc).  UMDNJ and SROH are seeking support from the community to as a way to cover the cost of this course.For more information there is also a podcast available and picture slideshow at: http://seen-heard.com/blog/?p=1238 
 
 

 
 
What We Need & Why (The Academia Hump to Get Over)
 
While we believe that improving bedside manner is a necessary part of medical education this course is not mandatory and therefore not funded by the university. Our hope is that by documenting the the positive changes that this course will be implemented as a part of mandatory core curriculum, and will be funded. Until then we need outside support to be able to offer this valuable and long lasting training available to young doctors who are embarking on their medical career.  In April 2012 Spring Reins of Hope partnered with UMDNJ and offered the course free of charge in order to gauge the interest / feedback / and engagement.   After completing the course, both students and administrators from UMDNJ applauded the impact that the horses had on students in the way of experiential learning and illustrating just how subtle body language can be to allow a patient to feel Safe - or - UN-safe. UMDNJ is exploring the viability around establishing this elective course into mandatory training required by M3 and M4 medical students to complete their training (maybe even eventually dental students, nurses, med techs, etc).
*To read student evaluations from the pilot April 2012 course - see the pdf file "Student Evals 2012" loaded in the GALLERY tab of this campaign.
However, this is a new modality (especially to the North-east USA) and getting a new class to be approved and also funded within academia is a large chore. There will need to be more proof! SROH would like to continue offering this course to young doctors in order to help ensure that future patients will meet up with trust and safety within their own healthcare provider network, right off the bat.  We believe that when a patient feels safe and secure (trusts) their health care provider and the decisions he/she makes on their behalf that there is an improved rapport right from the start. This trust and rapport will translate into the treatment plan, increased optimism, higher efforts to follow instructions, and possibly lower Mal-practice claims.
Each Mondays full day session has real costs associated with it running at approximately $1100 for each day. 2-3 facilitators, 4-8 horses, ring fees, facility fees, catering, insurance, etc. all adds up. Two full days at 1100 = $2,200. Indiegogo charges fees for this campaign fund-raising option.  If the entire goal is not met, SROH has agreed to run the course on whatever amount is raised applied to April 2013 class. We are hoping it will not end up costing the equine program money to provide this service. If the amount raised exceeds the total needed, any excess funds will be applied to the costs of the next Horses For Healers session (either Fall 2013 or Spring 2014).
 
   
 
The Impact (Why Does This Training Matter?)
 

The Horses for Healers workshop is an EAL (equine assisted learning) program that allows Medical Professionals (and students) to learn body language awareness and improve upon bedside manner. Horses are extremely sensitive to body language / intent vs. action which makes them superb barometers to gauge and to mirror back the congruency of our body language signals. Over time our big picture goal is to create a positive impact for medical professionals to have fantastic bedside manner, creating a different patient experience, relationship and rapport with their health care providers. Our short term goal is to provide 10-12 medical students in New Jersey with these skills to take with them into their practice and career right from the beginning. So in essence we believe that by funding and providing this one class - it will make a difference to the patients that these soon to be doctors will face in their practice. Its a start!
 
"Doctors would be far more respectful of their body language and bedside manners if their patients all weighed 1200 pounds; horses help medical students and professionals learn non-verbal communication skills demonstrating the powerful voice of our body's language".~ Dr. Allan Hamilton, MD, FACS From Barnside to Bedside; How Horses Teach Doctors the Secrets of Better Bedside Manner1(Course curriculum in over a dozen universities around the world)
 
The Horse Medicine Wheel ~ Horses for Healers:
75% of patients complain that their medical providers do not communicate well...2

How is your bedside manner?
High GPA, but low Press-Ganey survey scores?
Are you and your patients communicating clearly?
The Horse Medicine Wheel/Horses for Healers is a workshop specifically designed for healthcare professionals such as; doctors, dentists, nurses and clinical health science students, house staff, or other healthcare professionals--anyone with direct patient care responsibility. Because health science education stresses intellectual excellence, much less attention is placed on proficient communication, both verbal and non-verbal. Good communication can help increase patient satisfaction, therapeutic outcomes, and malpractice prevention to name a few [Stanford Medicine & Horsemanship, Kane, 2007].3
 

 
Learning to communicate with horses requires an appreciation for all the messages we send and receive as it demands patience, gentleness, self-confidence, sensitivity, focus and a keen awareness. Horses are large but also easily frightened - their survival as prey animals depends upon them being finely tuned to body language, emotional tone and to the position or movement of objects and other beings within their sensory fields. Through this work, medical professionals are able to increase their sensitivity to non-verbal awareness and communication as they explore the poise and self control to interact with a 1000 lb being, their ability to monitor and read the body language of their human patients becomes more refined.
By reflecting back to us the most subtle signals of our intent (that we may not be conscious of) the horses can teach us to be much more aware of the messages that we convey. Horses also can help us refine our instinctual, intuitive and sensory faculties that may have dulled due to pressure of exams/schooling, scientific reasoning, logical diagnosis, and clinical decision making. Horses can challenge us to overcome our fears/indecision and develop confidence, courage and conviction.
 

 
Horses also help medical professionals in that they remain true to their essence - they each have distinct personalities and moods - an approach that works with one horse may not work with another (much like human patients), we therefore have to find other ways to communicate, and generate respect within that relationship in order for it to be based on compassion and trust. Because horses react to the subtlest of our human signals, it is as if they are holding up a magnifying glass to our styles and behaviors. It is in this mirror that we can see our truest image and a path to professional development and growth.
Spring Reins of Hope has customized exercises for UMDNJ students to easily learn:

Improved rapport and communication with patients
Enhanced bedside manner and an improved understanding of non-verbal messages
Confidence building and more refined awareness of self presence
Management stress of time constraints with patients and maintain valued rapport

    

Why congruency / consistency are desirable for patient relations
A developed "Leave it at the Gate" mentality and non-intimidating ways to interact
About defined appropriate personal space and boundary setting techniques
Strategies for effectively managing challenging clinical situations with poise and self-control
Identified patterns of interaction, the reactions elicited by the horses and how that relates to both professional and personal identity


See the Emmy Winning NBC 11 News Coverage of Dr. Beverley Kane's Medicine and Horsemanship program at Stanford University
Resources on Professional Training and Development with Horses

 
1Allan Hamilton, MD, FACS, The Doctor Who Whispers to Horses at http://www.allanhamilton.com/equine.html2 [Moore et al., West J Med. 2000 October; 173(4): 244-250.]3The Horse Medicine Wheel workshop is based on the development and proven success of The Stanford Medicine & Horsemanship program at Stanford University, California, developed by Beverley Kane, MD at http://www.horsensei.com/#app=programs_medicine_horsemanship and http://med.stanford.edu/blogs/mandh/ 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
 
If you are interested in this idea but cannot contribute at this time...would you be willing to help us in other ways?

Please share this campaign on FB, Twitter, to your friends, family, maybe even to your doctor?
Do you have any contacts or connections to Doctors, Patient Care Advocates, Patient Relations Managers at Hospitals / Clinics? Those connections may have an invested interest in seeing ways to improve bedside manner and therefore may offer some (even if small) support to this idea...
Offer any ideas you may have to help raise money - a local bake sale, kitty jar, etc. Little bits do really add up! We may not have thought of everything, and we are all ears...


 
DONATIONS ARE NOT TAX DEDUCTIBLE! SROH IS AN LLC AND THEREFORE UNABLE TO PROVIDE TAX RECEIPTS. These donations are as a gift to up and coming medical students at UMDNJ to acquire the skills for patient communication and rapport, which will ultimately benefit society and community.
 
Horses For Healers Facilitators: 
Maria Katsamanis, PsyD - Clinical Assistant Professor, Department of Psychiatry/Robert Wood Johnson Medical School. Horses for Healers Workshop founder, EAGALA Mental Health Professional & Equine Specialist
Christianna Capra "CC" - CEO Spring Reins of Hope, EAGALA Equine Specialist
(Photos by: Dr. Shari Silverman, VMD of Simply Sound Horse, NJ)(Video by: Lynn Appel and Cheryl Galante, short edit by BlueRock, NJ)(Podcast by: Doris J. Gilman, Health Thought Leadership One-to-One)

story:
We've reached our goal!

Thank you all for you generosity and support.

The February JEP "Apprentice Challenge" is now fully funded and with time to spare.  So not to waste this wonderful opportunity we are going to keep fundraising and use any amount over the initial goal to fund the next stage of Young Entrepreneurs of Paraguay, our national business plan competition.

Come July, graduates of the "Build your Dreams" business course will be submitting business plans to be considered for seed funding from Young Entrepeneurs of Paraguay in order to make these businesses happen.  The entrepreneurs present their plans to a panel of Paraguayan business leaders during another three day event. At the end a young Paraguayan will receive over $1,000 in seed funding to start their business.  By continuing to support us, you will literally be investing in a future business in Paraguay!

Please play our updated video above to see a message from Carmen Benitez, winner of last year's business plan competition.

Thank you so much for your support!

 

“Young people don’t just learn how to fill jobs, but rather how to create them.” - José Méndez, President of the Young Entrepreneurs Association of Paraguay

THE PROBLEM:

Paraguay is a developing country with over half of the current population under the age of 25. A recent publication from the United Nations Development Programme reported that there is a 70% unemployment rate amongst Paraguayan youth ages 15 to 29. Additionally, there are only 8,000 job opportunities for the 40,000 youth that are entering the labor market every year. Youth face limited academic opportunities and lack available technical training in their communities.

 

THE OPPORTUNITY:

Many Paraguayan youth are eager to change their lives, but they lack guidance and the tools to develop their entrepreneurial spirit. Paraguay’s biggest resource is its people, and youth make up the largest percentage. They can move Paraguay forward by addressing needs in their communities through entrepreneurship. 

 

WHAT WE WANT TO DO:

Youth Entrepreneurs of Paraguay (JEP) and Young Entrepreneurs Association of Paraguay (AJE Paraguay) are hosting a nationwide business plan competition in July 2013. The participants, from all over Paraguay, will have participated a 4-month "Build Your Dreams" business course and created viable business plans that address needs in their communities. Each community will select the best business plan and bring their youth to compete in a national competition to win over $1,000 in seed funding to start their own business, enabling them to make their venture a reality. 

 

SUCCESSES:

Now in its second year, the JEP initiative has already helped many Paraguayans become entrepreneurs. Last year’s competition resulted in over 30 business plans and 10 start-ups created all over the country. Start-ups have included an organic lettuce business, a brick factory, a photography and design company, and a clothing store. Each venture has addressed needs in their communities, provided infrastructure, and created jobs. 

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

We need your support to make their ventures a reality! Your donation will go directly towards seed funding. The funds raised will create a truly transformative experience for youth looking to change their lives and create their own opportunities. 

You can also help us by sharing this campaign on social media and with your family and friends. To learn more about this inspiring event and see your donation in action, visit our website: http://jovenesempresariosdelparaguay.wordpress.com/ 

Thank you for your support, and for helping us kindle the entrepreneurial spirit in Paraguay’s youth. 

Jóvenes Empresarios del Paraguay (Youth Entrepreneurs of Paraguay), is a joint national initiative between Peace Corps Paraguay and the Young Entrepreneurs Association of Paraguay (AJE Paraguay), focused on developing entrepreneurial skills in Paraguayan youth. 

 

_____________________________________________________________________

"Los jóvenes aprenden no sólo a buscar trabajo sino a crear trabajo." - Jose Méndez, Presidente de la Asociación de Jóvenes Empresarios del Paraguay. 


Jóvenes Empresarios de Paraguay (JEP) es un proyecto nacional, en conjunto
con la Asociación de Jóvenes Empresarios del Paraguay (AJE) y Cuerpo de Paz, que apoya, alienta y desarrolla destrezas emprendedoras, de resolución de problemas y de planeamientos a futuro en la juventud paraguaya.

AJE y JEP están realizando un campamento nacional llamado "EL DESAFIO EMPRENDEDOR" en Asunción, que inspira los jóvenes participantes a ser los futuros líderes de negocios del Paraguay. Los participantes, provenientes de todas partes del Paraguay, desarrollan el espíritu empresarial y aprenden valiosas habilidades empresariales a través de actividades y desafíos dinámicos. Asimismo, el evento conecta a los jóvenes con empresarios paraguayos ya establecidos, quienes comparten conocimiento y consejos a través de charlas y conversaciones personales. Los participantes se van con la motivación de aprender más sobre negocios, poner sus conocimientos en práctica y hacer que sus sueños se conviertan en realidad mediante la creación de negocios sólidos e innovadores.

Queremos invitarle a ser parte de esta valiosa iniciativa, contribuyendo con aportes para estos jóvenes que tienen escaso acceso a oportunidades.

Con su aporte, AJE y Cuerpo de Paz pueden realizar este evento con los jóvenes de todo el Paraguay y sin costos para ellos y asegurando que la distancia geográfica no sea un factor limitante a la presencia de los mismos. El mencionado evento recibirá participantes de 11 departamentos y más de 25 ciudades y pueblos.  Su contribución servirá para cubrir los costos de transporte, alojamientos, y alimentación para los jóvenes.  

JEP, AJE, y Cuerpo de Paz le agradecen muy sinceramente su apoyo a esta iniciativa. Su contribución hace la diferencia!

story:
A CALL TO ARMS

In July 2008, after laying a friend to rest that was killed in action while conducting combat operations in support of Operation IRAQ FREEDOM, I was discussing with a mutual friend about various programs available to the families of service members that were wounded or killed in action (WIA/KIA).  It was during this conversation that his mother innocently offered the statement “Well I always thought you all took care of your own!”  For the past few years the loss of that friend and many more since, along with that statement have remained in the forefront of my days.

The truth of the matter is that as service members we know the risks involved with our occupation of arms and since 2001 we have knowingly and willingly placed ourselves in harms way on behalf of our country - like generations of service members before us.  While deployed we often times establish tighter bonds with people in our units then we have with the families that raised us; through shared adversity we persevere. 

The U.S. Department of Defense reports as of October 12, 2012 there were 3, 479 KIA and 31,930 WIA in support of Operation IRAQI FREEDOM and 1,672 KIA and 17,737 WIA in support of Operation ENDURING FREEDOM. 

Currently the US military stands just shy of 3 million service members (active/reserves) but these numbers do not take into account the countless veterans of previous wars or service members that have transitioned back into civilian roles. We have shown in wars throughout our nations history what we can do when we put our minds to it, so what would happen if we came together now?

HOW CAN YOU HELP

I am going to speak blasphemy for a moment and ask service members past, present, and future to forgo their daily “Cup of Joe” and donate whatever that amount is to Fallen Not Forgotten, Inc. – ONLY FOR 1 DAY!  I know that coffee is the staple ingredient that has powered the military throughout the years and that the military may grind to a halt so I am not asking for everyone to do it on the same day…and on behalf of all the junior service members definitely not on a Monday!  You pick the day and it only has to be one cup! (We are not trying to cost anyone his or her jobs here.)

Never served in the military, but still want to help?  If you are up for the challenge and think that you can handle the start to the day without caffeine….by all means join us!  We would love your continued support!

If you can’t afford a financial contribution there are other ways you can help.  For example simply getting the word out via social media such as Facebook, Twitter, Google Plus or any other way that people may connect with us is greatly appreciated. 

TAKING CARE OF OUR OWN

The College Board Advocacy & Policy Center states that the average estimated undergraduate budget for public four-year in-state on-campus students is $21,447, including tuition and fees, room and board, books and supplies, transportation, and other expenses as of 2011-2012.  If we were able to get EVERY active/reserve member to donate $1 (the price of a Cup of Joe from McDonald’s) we could send 139 wounded or fallen service members children to college at no out-of-pocket expense to them at today’s cost.  Imagine how amazing that would be!  As an organization, we are realists and have set the goal low initially to manage expectations – we welcome our expectations being surpassed and challenge everyone that visits this site to help us in doing so!

ABOUT THE PERKS (because you’ll need a pick me up after not having your daily Cup of Joe)

On the right sidebar of this page you’ll see that we’ve created a few “perks” to help you determine what level of contribution you’d like to make.  Please note that you do not have to claim a perk in order to contribute.  Just click the “contribute now” button below and follow the instructions.  If you’d like to claim a perk, please do and share that experience with your friends.

 Like the selfless service to your country, the biggest reward is internal pride of knowing that you have not forgotten the sacrifices of our fallen WIA/KIA and the ongoing struggles of their families as they continue on.

 SPECIAL NOTE FROM THE PRESIDENT OF FALLEN NOT FORGOTTEN, INC:

I am an active duty service member that has not forgotten.  I, like many of you, have experienced the loss of many friends throughout the past eleven years and know in my heart that these are not “someone else’s kids” …these are now our sons and daughters and they deserve our help to ensure they are well taken care of.  We must take care of our own!

Thank you for visiting the site and taking the time to consider a donation!

story:
Our Story

â€œPeace Begins with Understandingâ€ is a campaign to promote appreciation of global and cultural diversity among individuals through foreign language, artistic, and musical instruction. At All Learners Language and Culture Center, we believe that we can help our students become more globally aware through instruction in art, music, and culture. This awareness helps our students to understand the differences between cultures; and hopefully generate a more peaceful future. 

The All Learners Language & Culture Center, LLC is a company with mission and a conscience that was begun by Lindsay Mitchell. Our mission is to provide students with an exciting learning opportunity that will allow them to experience and understand a different culture. We believe that anyone should have the opportunity to learn about a different culture. As a result, all classes are priced so that as many people can afford the classes as possible. We currently offer foreign language classes; and will be starting with art and music classes in the coming months. We have 'give back' programs that encourage our students to donate to local organizations.

The conscience of All Learners lies within its belief that peace truly does come from learning. We believe that much of the violence that occurs in this world (whether it is physical or verbal) could be prevented or at least mitigated if time was taken to understand the other side. Therefore, All Learners seeks to be a company that aims for a greater good within its community.

This spring our goal is to release our first series of books that teach children a foreign language and promote global awareness. These foreign language books are ones that parents can easily read to their child and include a pronunciation key (along with definition). We also hope to release a book entited "Little Champion", which empowers students to change their local and global communities. These funds will allow us to price these materials at a low, affordable rate and to maintain our low tuition rates. This campaign will run for 60 days starting on February 15th.

The Impact

 

By contributing to this campaign, you are helping us expand our influence among our students and our community. With the funds that we receive, we will release 2 books in French, 2 in Spanish; and 1 book promoting global awareness and community. We will also attend local and regional expos to promote our mission and our message.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise $5000. Each book costs about $800 including pre-print editing, set up costs, and final printing. Therefore, printing 5 books (2 Spanish, 2 French, 1 English) will require a total cost of $4000. The remaining $1000 will be used to help defray our costs in upcoming expos and events where we will promote our mission and message.

 

Our perks for our donors will be first edition and signed copies of our new books and T-shirts that promote the mission of the company. Our books include "Hola Pedro" and "Bonjour Pierre". These teach children the basics of Spanish and French conversation; and these do include a vocabulary/pronunciation key for parents. Our third book is "Little Champion" which empowers children to change their local and global communities.

 

For T shirts, we have a children's "Peace" T-shirt that features the penguin from our books. He is standing in front of a globe with 'peace' written in multiple languages (look at our thumbnail to get an idea of what it will look like). For the adults, we have a light blue T-shirt that says "Peace Begins with Understanding" in front of a globe.

 
Other Ways You Can Help!

 

Please help us! Friend us on Facebook, Twitter, send all family and friends a link to this page. At All Learners, we firmly believe in our goal and mission. Any funds we raise will be used to help spread learning and hopefully greater peace and understanding.

story:
In a Nutshell

Hi. We are Angie's Book Nook, Independent Consultants for Usborne Books. There is me, Angie, and my husband Bruce. We work from our home in Burlington, Wisconsin. We work with schools, libraries, day care centers and individuals to provide quality books to children. We have teamed up with Bernie's Book Bank to provide quality books to at-risk kids.  But we need your help.

We would like to raise $1,100 to purchase new books for these kids, most of whom have no books in their homes! So we're turning to our strongest supporters to ask for contributions. In exchange, we're offering some of our quality books. Your contribution will help us get kids excited about reading and prepare them for the careers of tomorrow! Thanks for your support!

The Impact

Did you know that 61% of at-risk families have no books at all in their homes for their children? Book ownership is a non-negotiable in any successful educational journey. By donating, you will help children develop reading skills that they will use to shape tomorrow.

Recently, Angie's Book Nook helped a small home daycare get over $176 in FREE BOOKS! And Bernie's Book Bank distributes books to thousands of at-risk children in Chicagoland who have no books of their own! Bernie's Book Bank currently serves more than 35,000 children in Chicago and its suburbs.

Why $1,100?

If we can meet our goal, Usborne Books will match 50% of all donations! But we need to raise at least $1,100 to qualify for the match and pay Indiegogo's fees. Won't you please help us reach this goal?

Other Ways You Can Help

  • The best way you can help us is to get the word out! Use those share tools! Post it on Facebook! Tweet it! Text it! Tell anyone and everyone you can!
  • Donate your gently-used children's books to Bernie's Book Bank: CLICK HERE to learn more.
  • Volunteer at Bernie's Book Bank: CLICK HERE to learn more.
  • Host an Usborne Party and donate the books to Bernie's Book Bank: CLICK HERE to learn about hosting parties.
  • If you want to help in your own area, volunteer to read at a local school, or better yet, join my team! That way, you, too, can work with schools, libraries, day care centers and even individuals to bring free books to kids who desperately need them!

story:
Summary

I am presently a graduate student in an Experimental Psychology Master’s program. As part of professional development I am expected to attend at least two professional conferences in 2014. At these conferences we present research projects we have been working on for the past year, attend informational workshops, round table discussions and network with other psychology programs. Attending is a great way to make contacts for future research and to look into doctoral programs we may want to enroll in after graduation from our current program.

  Last year our undergraduate Educational Psychology research group presented at the Southwestern Psychological Association (SWPA) regional conference in Fort Worth, Texas. We were able to present five projects we had just finished. This was an exciting and educational experience that helped solidify my choice of Experimental Psychology as a career.

This year we plan on attending SWPA again, in San Antonio, Texas, as well as, the Association for Psychological Science (APS) national conference in San Francisco, California. Our main obstacle this year is funding. Unfortunately, our department can only reimburse us for $100-$200 per person for travel expenses. We estimate our total expense to be $2,500 per person this year. This includes all of our transportation, hotel and food costs.

  As a group we are planning several fundraising projects throughout the year to reach our goal such as, a small organizational grant, a garage sale and possibly a bake sale. I am also pursuing a few other opportunities to raise funds on my own (this website) and with a graduate psychology club (a t-shirt fundraiser, and Amazon partnership). I have also applied to be a volunteer for the APS conference. The volunteer position will reimburse up to $300 in hotel costs if I am accepted.

  My research interests include improving academic success and influences on student motivation; this can be clearly seen in all of my projects this year. They include:

Underprepared Undergraduates- An intervention to assist undergraduates in learning study skills appropriate to the demands of collegiate coursework with an emphasis on increasing their overall academic motivation.

Religiosity, Stress and Academic Motivation- A survey of undergraduate students, evaluating their use of religious resources as a form of social support, increasing their academic motivation.

Student Writing Anxiety and Motivation- Evaluation of undergraduate beliefs about basic writing and anxiety toward academic writing styles. A pilot study to assist in designing an intervention.

What I Need 

Conference

Presenting

Fees

Hotel

(Split 2 ways)

Transport

Food

Southwestern Psychological Association

April 3-5, 2014

San Antonio, Texas

SWPA Convention 2014

Underprepared Undergraduates

and

Religiosity, Stress and Academic Motivation

Dues $20

Registration $20

$149/night

Plane Ticket- $280.00

Parking- $30.00

Shuttle- $30.00

$60.00/day (estimated from last year)

Association for Psychological Sciences

May 22-25

San Francisco, California

APS Convention 2014

Student Writing Anxiety and Motivation

Dues $78

Registration $205

$189/night

Plane Ticket-$612.00

Parking- $30.00

Shuttle- $60.00

$60.00/day (estimated from last year)

Total Need for Academic Year 2013/2014

$2,293.00 (My goal is  $2,500 in case of unforeseen expenses)



By assisting in my fundraising efforts you are helping me take the next step in my education and psychological research career. Since I am pursuing other fundraising avenues, my goal for fundraising from this website is $1,000. Every little bit helps, even if I am unable to reach this goal, all funds will be added together and used to pay as many of the conference expenses as possible. Any funds received above my goal will be donated to the undergraduate Educational Psychology Club travel budget.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a donation, simply forward my link to others who might be interested. Thanks in advance!

If you are fasicnated by academic research or just want to keep an eye on my progress you can follow my thesis project blog online at:

http://experimentalpsycher.tumblr.com/

To view my CV:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B3e5HWvX81Q0Sy1RWHd4aUpnM2M/edit?usp=sharing

story:
Short Summary

Every year, a group of students (such as ourselves) work together to organize the Southeastern LGBTQ+ Student Conference, an annual gathering of lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans*, asexual, and queer students from colleges, high schools, and communities across the Southeast. The conference is a weekend jam packed with workshops, discussions, activities, social events, food, presentations, lectures, and panels all with one unified goal in mind: building LGBTQ+ community in the Southeast.

This year's conference is being hosted by students from The University of Alabama on February 21st-23rd, 2014 in Tuscaloosa, Alabama. We're thrilled to be hosting this meaningful event!

What We Need & What You Get

The Southeastern LGBTQ+ Student Conference is a massive undertaking. Last year's conference saw hundreds of attendees enjoying over two dozen unique events over the course of two days. What's more, last year's conference was offered with no registration fee for attendees, something we're striving to continue this year.

The reason we make it a goal to offer the conference free of charge is to broaden the scope of individuals who can attend the event as a result. This means that the entirety of our conference budget comes from grassroots fundraising such as this. We have a kick ass team of full time students working around the clock, but we can't do it without your help.

Your contribution will go directly to offsetting the cost of this year's conference: reserving space for events, booking speakers, assisting with presenters' travel costs, providing refreshments for attendees, printing programs and promotional materials, etc.

We've arranged some exciting rewards for our supporters, which you can see just to the right. Additionally, every contributor will be listed on our website. 

The Impact

Members of last year's conference planning committee with speakers Mandy Carter and Eli Strong.

The positive impact of the Southeastern LGBTQ+ Student Conference doesn't end after the final conference session. The hope is that the knowledge gained, conversations started, and friendships began at the conference will continue to grow and become part of the greater Southeastern LGBTQ+ community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to contribute financially but still want to support the conference? Not to worry! There is plenty to do, and we are so grateful for your help!

If you're interested in attending the conference, find more information as it becomes available on our website and Facebook page. If you're interested in helping us out during the conference, stay tuned for ways for ways to volunteer with us. Volunteers are an essential part of the conference running smoothly.

If you or your group would like to present at this year's conference, click here to submit a proposal. We'd love to hear what you have to offer us!

If you won't be able to join us for the conference but would still like to help, please feel free to spread the word about the conference to your friends and family, either by sharing our website, Facebook page, or this campaign.

If you have any questions or comments, please don't hesitate to email us at selgbtqconference@gmail.com.

Thank you for your support!
