story:
What would happen to your family if you didn’t get paid for 20 weeks or more?
That is what is facing British Columbia teachers.   With the strike days; lockout; and 10% pay cut imposed in June, they have already foregone about a month of pay just before the two months they normally do not get paid in the summer.  

With no progress in bargaining, the looming reality is that the likelihood of any school in the first two weeks of September is negligible... meaning the first remotely likely payday for teachers will be at the end of September.  A fourth month without a paycheque coming in.

If the government is to be believed, and that they won't be bringing back the legislature prior to the scheduled 6th of October, we could be facing the start of the school year in mid October and the first payday for teachers at the end of October.


They have taken on the fight of ensuring that there is sufficient support for your kids in the classrooms (if this was about wages a deal would be done as the parties are very close in their numbers).
We are raising money to support the temporary food banks that have been set up to help struggling teacher families who just are not able to make ends meet after not getting paid for months, and facing the prospect of missing many more paycheques.
Your support also shows the government that you support teachers and the education system and that they are risking a lot of votes by continuing this dispute.

#### Donating via Paypal instead of via credit card is the preferred method as it allows us to get the cash into the hands of those who need it the quickest####
BACKGROUND


The courts have ruled repeatedly that the government broke the law in stripping class size and composition from collective bargaining. The courts also found overwhelming evidence that the government acted in bad faith, hoping to gain political advantage rather than considering the educational needs of our children.

These are not people making politician kind of money. They are everyday folks. Many of them are hurting financially as they are just starting out at the bottom of the pay scale and servicing massive student debt from getting the training required for their jobs. Many are single parent families with no other income. Many are families where both parents are teachers without any other source of income.

The British Columbia government has come up with a gimmick to pay parents NOT to send their kids to school by distributing the money they aren't paying for teachers’ salaries to parents while the strike/lockout is on.
If you are in a position to help financially by kicking back some of that money the government is sending to you, or just want to show support, please donate to help out. All proceeds will go to filling the needs of these teacher food banks across the province.

This campaign is created by concerned parents and citizens and is not affiliated in any way with the BC Teachers Federation. 

If the dispute is resolved unexpectedly, any finds not already disbursed will go towards local Children's breakfast and lunch programs at inner city schools in British Columbia.

story:
Maof Program

Maof at-risk youth program is a voluntary initiative (started in September 2013) with the intention of giving young people a unique experience and a better chance to succeed.

The basis of our activity is youth education through aviation and flying. 
The world of flight and aviation has a special appeal; Taking part in this exclusive group boosts self-confidence, while engaging in related activities produces a significant sense of accomplishment. These are very powerful tools when dealing with at-risk youth.

We began by recruiting volunteers to coach, lecture and advise on both theoretical issues and practical instruction. With them, we built uniqueand empowering program aimed to educate youth at the Branco Weiss School in Qiryat Shemona.


Giving Opportunities, Changing Lives

July 2014 marked the culmination of a very successful first year, and now we are working to expand and solidify our activities. The goal of our campaign is to raise funds in order to continue the Maof program and establish the Aeronautical Education Center using the knowledge and experience we have gained.

The participants in our programs come from underprivileged neighborhoods. Programs like Maof provide at-risk youth with an opportunity to try something new and exposes them to fields of excellence and professionalism, developing skills and abilities that help these young people in every aspect of their lives. 

Your contribution will help us establish an organization based on the educational infrastructure we have already built, and create a program that will help and educate many more young people. $70,000 will grant 60 youngsters life-changing opportunities over a period of three years and lay foundations for our future activity. 

What We Need 

The Maof program is based on the time and expertise donated by many volunteers, and is financed by donations from incredible people and organizations. Unfortunately, not all of them are able to donate this year, and now we are asking for your help.

Our goal is to raise enough money to build a sustainable organization that relies solely on its business activity, and employs graduates of the program. The school year begins September 1st and we need have at least $24,000 for the upcoming year. Branco Weiss School committed to fund $5,700 so we aim to reach a goal of 18,000 with this campaign. $70,000 will take us through the next 3 years!


Our Community of Supporters 

By contributing to the Aeronautical Education Center, you become an ambassador of good will and a member of our founding supporters community. All the money we raise goes solely to fund the education of youth. 

As an ambassador, we would like you to have something from the Aeronautical Education Center – something with the spirit that drives our team, the team of which you are now a member. Moreover, when people see you carrying an item with the Aeronautical Education Center logo, it raises awareness of youth education,
and thus keeps alive the spirit we are all trying to maintain!




Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, you can still help! You can:

  • Spread the word and make some noise about the campaign!
  • Volunteer with us! We are always looking for qualified volunteers to help us. 
    If you want to help, all you need is to coordinate with us and come on over!

We appreciate your support at any level. Every cent counts. 
Times are tough these days and we understand that not everyone can donate. 
We do hope you'll help us by spreading the word on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook and using by the Indiegogo share tools so that your family, friends, and co-workers may consider supporting this campaign. 

Your support gives an opportunity to those who need it, supporting at-risk youth. Thank you.

Our Thanks

We would like to thank Mr. Stef Wertheimer, and all the donors in the past year,
for giving us the opportunity to give an opportunity:

Thank you to all the volunteers that donated their time this year and came to lecture, teach, tutor or just to lend a hand. We appreciate it!

And a special thanks to all the volunteers who made this campaign!

  • Odin Shadmi (Wix) for all the graphic design!
  • Mr. Paul Gluck - for donating his voice!
  • Golan Studio - Qiryat Shemona for the photography and film editing!
  • Jony Geron - for the editing and subtitles!

Thank you all! You are amazing!

Maof Program


Maof at-risk youth program is a voluntary initiative (started in September 2013)
with the intention of giving young people a unique experience and a better
chance to succeed.
The basis of our activity is youth
education through aviation and flying. 
The world of flight and aviation has a
special appeal; Taking part in this exclusive group boosts self-confidence,
while engaging in related activities produces a significant sense of
accomplishment. These are very powerful tools when dealing with at-risk youth.
We began by recruiting
volunteers to coach, lecture and advise on both theoretical issues and
practical instruction. With them, we built uniqueand empowering program aimed to educate youth at
the Branco Weiss School in Qiryat Shemona.



Giving Opportunities, Changing Lives

July 2014 marked the culmination of a very successful first year, and now we are working to expand and solidify our activities. The goal of our campaign
is to raise funds in order to continue the Maof program and establish the Aeronautical Education Center using the
knowledge and experience we have gained.

The participants in our programs come from underprivileged
neighborhoods. Programs like Maof provide at-risk youth
with an opportunity to try something new and exposes them to fields
of excellence and professionalism, developing skills and abilities that help
these young people in every aspect of their lives. 

Your contribution will help us
establish an organization based on the educational infrastructure we have already built,
and create a program that will help and educate many more young
people. $70,000 will grant 60 youngsters life-changing opportunities over a period of three years and
lay foundations for our future activity. 

What We Need 
 
The Maof program is based on the time and expertise donated by many volunteers, and is financed by donations from incredible people and organizations. Unfortunately, not all of them are able to donate this year, and now we are asking for your help.Our goal is to raise enough money to build a
sustainable organization that relies solely on its business activity, and
employs graduates of the program. The school year begins September 1st

story:
­­The Story

Our goal is to design, fund, and build a primary school in Burkina Faso, Africa. Our mission is to create a sustainable and dignifying architectural design that will celebrate the culture, environment, and materials of the region to further empower the communities of Burkina Faso. Our total funding goal of $32,000 will cover the construction of a primary school that will serve over 135 children. 

Burkina Faso has a 28.7% literacy rate. 

Only 58% of children attend primary school. 


WHY?! 

Burkina Faso is the 5th economically poorest country in the world. The challenging economy causes a lack of schools. Therefore, children often do not have access to a safe and healthy learning environment. 


For Burkina is more than a non-profit organization. It is the story of young design professionals and university students, whom decided to unite over their passion to make a positive impact in Burkina Faso. The primary school design that For Burkina has created will be donated to their partners, buildOn, and will be used by buildOn for all primary schools built in Burkina Faso and Mali starting in 2015. Representatives from the For Burkina Team will travel to Burkina Faso to help build the first school using the new prototype design. 

In design, economy is paramount and with a budget of $32,000 our price per square foot is below $6, making it less than 1/25 of what a low budget school in the U.S. would cost. The intention of the design was to make a functional learning environment that would respond to the climate and the culture while minimizing the material cost. In order to accomplish this, our team had to employ innovative, yet simple construction methods. The resulting design lent itself to an even stronger program, having outdoor classrooms that create opportunities for further learning and community development.

You can see more about the school design here:

http://issuu.com/forburkinafaso/docs/for_burkina


What We Need


For Burkina is 100% volunteer based. Out of the $32,000 needed for the project, $15,357 goes directly towards the materials. The remaining $16,625 goes towards paying the few local skilled laborers and staff on the ground in Burkina Faso in addition to other overhead costs, such as material transportation.

The school is built by the local villagers who will be utilizing the school. Every member of the community signs (or fingerprints) a covenant, that is a solemn promise outlining the community member's responsibilities for the project. The village provides the land, local materials, and unskilled labor. The village also promises to send boys and girls to school in equal numbers (something that is often not the case in developing countries).


The Impact IS BIGGER! 


Humanitarian architecture is architecture that uses the natural and built environment to improve the welfare and livelihood of its inhabitants. Within humanitarian architecture sustainable designs play a significant role in positively impacting the community, economy, and environment. By promoting the positive impact of humanitarian architecture, more university students and professionals in the field of architecture and design are able to participate in these types of life-changing projects. 


Perks! 

For your financial contribution you will receive one or more of the perks listed along the right side of your screen. Donate to make a difference in the lives of many, and as a small token of our "thank-you" we will send you the perk that matches your donation amount! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution at this time, there are other ways you can make a difference. Please help promote For Burkina via social media - Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, etc. Please re-post our Indigeogo campaign and share with your friends and family. 

Other ways to help:

Organize a group at your school or church or recruit an existing group to help promote For Burkina.  

Run a race or participate in another event in honor of For Burkina. Have people donate to For Burkina for your success! If you have questions on how to organize this kind of event contact us at Team@forburkinafaso.com.  


Frequently Asked Questions

Are you a non-profit? Can I write-off my contribution with my taxes?

Yes. For Burkina is a registered 501©3 nonprofit. Contributions to For Burkina are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. For Burkina’s tax ID number is 47-1313531.

How can I get my tax deductible receipt?

When you contribute, you will receive an email from FirstGiving (Indiegogo’s nonprofit payments processor) confirming your contribution. You will also receive an official receipt from For Burkina via email after the campaign ends.

Why Should I Help?

To date, For Burkina has raised $13,500 from supporting individuals. To finish this project, For Burkina still needs $18,500. For Burkina is about more than just building a school; it is about changing the lives of over 135 children and their families. It is about changing statistics on illiteracy. It is about spreading the importance of humanitarian architecture, revealing the significant impact that design has within the developing world. It is about humanity and our connection to one another.  It is about the impact that ripples out farther than any one of us may ever truly know. All donations, regardless of the amount, help to further our mission and this project.



Is there an alternative way to donate to this campaign if I do not want to donate online or by a credit / debit card?

Yes! You can mail a check or money order to For Burkina at 213 W. Olive St. #202 Springfield, MO 65806.

Can I donate from outside of the USA?

Yes! Indiegogo only accepts international credits cards, no bank or debit cards. So, the only way to donate internationally is with a credit card.

How can I make a contribution over $10,000?

The nonprofit payment processor (FirstGiving) that is handling the transactions for this campaign is able to accept direct wire transfers for contributions of $10,000 or more. If you are interested in making a large contribution through a wire transfer to FirstGiving, please contact us at Team@forburkinafaso.com. We will connect you with a specialist at Indiegogo who will assist you with the contribution transfer process.

Why do you ask for my shipping address when I donate?

For Burkina wants to make sure that we can provide every donor with a tax-deductible receipt for their generosity. We ask for your shipping address to ensure that we can get your receipt to you. We will not share your personal information. 

I have more questions, who can I talk to?

Please email For Burkina at Team@forburkinafaso.com and we will get back to you as soon as we can.

story:
CLC Montreal is a language school with a big heart and an even bigger mission. Our name stands for Culture and Language Connections – a reflection of how we help people find greater richness in life through conversation, culture and connections.

As we do the business of language instruction differently, we're prototyping something vitally important in society: We strive to be a social economy enterprise that demonstrates what's possible when profits are used to enrich the lives of those it touches and the community that enfolds it.

Since we opened our doors three years ago, the school has grown into something undeniably special. With dynamic, friendly teachers, a carefully crafted teaching methodology, small class sizes and personalized instruction, we're exceedingly good at helping people speak a new language with confidence and ease. What truly makes the school stand out, though, is the way people flourish comfortably in our space. We've been called the language school that “feels like home, no matter where you're from.”

Right now, our reach is limited to our space, so we invite your support to share this feeling and enrich lives of others overseas and within corporations. It would directly fund each of our following goals:

  • Apply for accreditation in our industry to attract more international students
  • Develop our B2B (Business-to-Business) partnerships to engage employees within corporations
  • Update our marketing tools to make it easier for people to connect with us


In exchange for helping us with our goals, we'd love to help you find greater richness in your life. At the heart of each of the perks, we're offering a piece of language learning - the CLC way. We can't think of any better way to show our gratitude.  The impact of your generosity and support will go well beyond the walls of our school.

The poet Rumi once said: “Speak a new language so that the world will be a new world.” With your help, our version of that might be: “Teach a new language so that the world will be a new world.” A world worth living in.

Thank you for your support.

The CLC Montreal Team



March 31, 2014 Update:

1) New perk available from our friends at Crudessence:  For $50, you will receive Crudessence's Raw Essence book which contains a wide variety of recipes for raw food cooking AND your name written with a shodo brush in Japanese on Japanese calligraphy rice paper. 

2) Connect and chat with our teachers on Skype on Friday April 4, 2014, from 9am - 10am (Montreal time).

English language Skype chat:
Skype name for chat with English teachers: CLCMontreal
Chat session will be led by Tina Lee

French language Skype chat:
Skype name for chat with French teachers: CLCMontreal1
Chat session will be led by Yohann Cesa

story:
• I'm Sara Shusterman, a 13 month Program Director working for Manna Project International, a 501(c)3 organization focused on making sustainable, holistic development.  I am currently living in Nicaragua and am working on programs that focus on livelihood, education, and health.  We work in the community of Cedro Galán, which is home to over 450 families living just above the global poverty line of $1.25 per day.  We also work in Villa Guadalupe, which was La Chureca, once the largest municipal dump in Central America. 
  •  I teach English, Girls Sexual and Reproductive Health, Women’s Exercise and Nutrition class, as well as help run a Women’s Jewelry Cooperative and a Child Sponsorship program.  We have 50 children in our Child Sponsorship program, which is run out of Villa Guadalupe.  Every three months I run hematocrit tests to check for anemia and prescribe iron according to the results.  Most importantly, we recently opened a medical clinic in our community Cedro Galán.  Before the clinic, the community did not have access to affordable healthcare nearby.  Since the opening of the clinic in October, we have already seen many patients lead healthier and happier lives due to our ability to provide follow-up care.  With your donation we can broaden the types and amounts of medications that we can provide for the community, as well as provide iron for the children in our Child Sponsorship.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.  I need to raise a total of $3,000, which goes towards administrative, living, and mostly program expenses.  Living in Nicaragua, I have seen the difference we can make with a little money.  Enhancing the quality of our programs is pertinent for making an even bigger difference; for getting kids back into school, preparing a greater number of community members for jobs, and for providing more comprehensive medical care. 
  • Any donation is so incredibly appreciated.  Spreading the word about our work is also extraordinarily valuable.  If you would like to do more, please forward this video.

story:
Quick Blurb:

Thank you for reading more about our campaign!

We are a small, inspired-by-Waldorf school for children ages 3-6.  In response to the needs of our small community for holistic, developmentally appropriate schooling, we opened our school 3.5 years ago. 

We have experienced great success and have built quite a wonderful community of families and friends.

One aspect for us that has been challenging is financing the continued educational needs of our teachers.  We strive to keep tuition costs low and do not include teacher education in our budget. Instead, we meet these needs through additional fundraising.  This year an amazing training opportunity, Lifeways Early Childhood Certification, is coming to our area.  This training has been on our radar for many years but has been located too far away to make attendance realistic.  This year it is coming to our town!  We hope to raise enough money to send at least one teacher through this certification program. 


Who we are:

The Little Round Schoolhouse is a home-based program inspired-by-Waldorf for children 3-6 years old.  We are devoted to providing a quality program that meets the physical, social-emotional, mental, and spiritual needs of young children.  We recognize and value the magic of early childhood and want to create a space that honors and nurtures our young children.
 
We draw a great amount of inspiration from the Waldorf model of early childhood education, which doesn’t include any formal academics but sets the foundation for academic learning later in life.  We believe that play is the true work of childhood and that learning by doing provides a framework for problem solving and critical thinking, as well as a love for lifelong learning.
 
We surround our children with simple, natural toys and experiences.  We let the children do things directly for themselves, trusting in their natural development and growth.
 
Each day begins with circle time, where children will enjoy songs, movements, verses, and finger plays that recognize and celebrate the cycles of the natural world.  Story time is also an important aspect of our daily rhythm and children will use stories to engage in drama and puppetry.
 
Children are served natural, nutritious snacks (made with their help!).  They enjoy a daily rhythm of activities including free indoor and outdoor play, nature walks, watercolor painting, baking, beeswax modeling, gardening, handwork and sewing, and seasonal crafts. 


What We Need:

Here is what we need to make it possible:

- Program tuition: $3750

- Supply fee: $500

- Mentor fee: $500

- Books & other supplies: $500

In the event that we don't raise all the money necessary, we will use whatever has been to go toward sending a teacher to Lifeways training.  If we raise money in addition to the amount listed above, we will set it aside for future teacher training and educational opportunities.

The Impact

Your involvement in this campaign will help us to attend this powerful and transformative teacher training. 

This training is specific for home-based early childhood care providers and will add a depth and beauty to what we already do here at Little Round Schoolhouse.

Your contribution will be felt by children for years to come.

children.  We recognize and value the magic of early childhood and want to
create a space that honors and nurtures our young children.
 
We draw a great amount of inspiration from the Waldorf model of early childhood
education, which doesn’t include any formal academics but sets the foundation
for academic learning later in life.  We believe that play is the true
work of childhood and that learning by doing provides a framework for problem
solving and critical thinking, as well as a love for lifelong learning.
 
We surround our children with simple, natural toys and experiences.  We
let the children do things directly for themselves, trusting in their natural
development and growth.
 
Each day begins with circle time, where children will enjoy songs, movements,
verses, and finger plays that recognize and celebrate the cycles of the natural
world.  Story time is also an important aspect of our daily rhythm and
children will use stories to engage in drama and puppetry.
 
Children are served natural, nutritious snacks (made with their help!). 
They enjoy a daily rhythm of activities including free indoor and outdoor play,
nature walks, watercolor painting, baking, beeswax modeling, gardening,
handwork and sewing, and seasonal crafts.  What We Need:
Here is what we need to make it
possible:
- Program tuition: $3750
- Supply fee: $500
- Mentor fee: $500 

- Books & other supplies: $500
In the
event that we don't raise all the money necessary, we will use whatever 
has
been to go toward sending a teacher to Lifeways training.  If we raise 
money in addition to the amount listed above, we will set it aside for 
future teacher training and educational opportunities.

The Impact
Your involvement in this campaign will
help us to attend this powerful and transformative teacher training.  This training is specific for
home-based early childhood care providers and will add a depth and beauty to
what we already do here at Little Round Schoolhouse.
Your contribution will be felt by children for years to come.

story:
One Wish to Fulfill a Thousand More

Help us open a girls' school in Kangra, Pakistan to help provide education to those who need it most. Help us bring to life the courageous dream Sonia Shah had for a better world before tragically passing away at only 18 years of age. 

“I want to leave this world knowing that I have changed it in some quantifiable, positive way, no matter how miniscule. I want to make history, instead of just witnessing it.” -Sonia Shah

In Kangra, Pakistan, only 3 out of 10 girls ever go to school, and hardly any of them ever get to high school. In Pakistan there are over three million girls not in school, and almost half (49%) of the girls who do begin primary school leave before completing the final grade. 

This is especially troubling, as by 2050, Pakistan will have the 4th largest population in the world behind, China, India and the USA. Yet Pakistan only spends 2.7% of its annual GDP on education, spending seven-times that on defense. The effects of such a poor education system are evident. Pakistan’s total literacy rate is a dismal 50%, while only 36% of Pakistani women are literate. 


Literacy translates directly to success in the workforce.  Women with a secondary education earn 70% of what men earn; with a primary education, they earn 51% of what men earn.   Illiterate women with no completed education earn even less.  Yet perhaps most astounding of all, women with a high level of literacy earn 95% more than women who are illiterate. 

Sonia Shah made it her mission, despite her young age, to change the lives of thousands of girls in Kangra, Pakistan by building a girls’ school herself and providing desperately needed education.  Yet Sonia's story was tragically cut short before she could see the opening of the school.

Sonia's Story

Sonia was an exceptional girl. She spoke five languages, was the youngest intern in the President's Campaign of 2012, and kept the needs of others above her own. She completed her education a year early and at only 17 years old, she dedicated a gap year to go to Kangra, Pakistan and build a school for the girls of the village. 

Sonia was determined that she would get to know the women of Kangra, understand their needs and then do what it takes to help improve their lives.  Sonia created a non-profit foundation to accomplish her task, and, in typical Sonia fashion, the foundation was in the name of her beloved grandmother, the Kulsoom Foundation. 

Speaking 5 languages herself, she planned a bilingual school for girls with a curriculum that would be taught in Urdu and in English.  She procured the land, gathered the necessary donations, established the curriculum, began the search for the teachers, and oversaw the groundbreaking of the building.

For a girl born and raised in the United States and Europe to go live in a rural Pakistani village, amongst the village women, and observe and respect the conservative social norms – takes courage, resolve and a heart of gold. These attributes are the spirit of Sonia.

And then just as her dreams for the school were about to take flight, her young life was tragically cut short. Usually, when a person passes away at this young an age, people speculate on what this person would have achieved if they had lived for a longer time.  However, in the case of Sonia, we find ourselves wondering how this unusual girl was able to achieve so much and impact so many in her all too brief eighteen years of life. 

Sonia’s mother, a woman whom she revered for her ambition, intelligence, and heart, carries on the efforts in Pakistan, fulfilling Sonia’s dream as her legacy. Sonia’s story and dreams for girls in Pakistan have inspired so many to give their time and resources to help make this dream a reality.

The School's Status

In 2013 we raised funds to build the school building, and we are excited that building will be completed in June.  We open the Sonia Shah Memorial School to the first class in September, but before we can do that, we have to raise money to fill the school with so many necessary items, including desks, computers, books, tables, and more.  

This campaign is for those set-up expenses of the school. The total amount we are trying to raise is $17,000 for the following expenses: 

  • Furniture, including desks, chairs, fans, white boards, tables and other essentials
  • Computer Lab, including computers, printers, and equipment for video-aided teaching
  • Library, including bookshelves, books, chairs, and desks
  • Play Room and Swings
  • Educational Games for Kindergarten students

How You Can Help

Your contributions will directly help launch a desperately needed school for girls in Kangra, Pakistan. 

Help us fulfill Sonia's dream of a girls’ school in her ancestral village which will, in turn, help fulfill a thousand dreams. Every dollar that you contribute goes directly towards the set-up expenses of the school, and every donation is vital to the success of the Sonia Shah Memorial School. 

Together we can  provide education for girls in Kangra, Pakistan and change their lives, and the lives of their children, forever.

story:
Short Summary:

"You're fat."                           "You're gay." 
                       "You're ugly."                          "You suck!"

                                    Have you been bullied?
Pretty much everyone has, but how that turned out for you depends on your self-esteem. Confident kids shrug it off, laugh it off, or dish it back. Kids who are unsure of themselves, who lack confidence, will get upset, cry or run away. Those behaviors almost guarantee that you’ll be bullied again. And, once you see yourself as a victim, the bullies seem to come out of the woodwork.  #bullybackoff

I was bullied when I was a kid. I was a victim. And, from age 5 to 14, I suffered dozens of verbal and physical attacks. I eventually learned how to deal with bullies, but it took me years to learn.

Today, it is my goal to teach as many elementary school aged kids as possible how to deal with bullies. Why elementary school? Because the sooner a kid learns to stand up to bullies the better. Bullying doesn’t go away with childhood; it follows you into adulthood. It never goes away, until you make it go away.


I’m Rob Wilson; I’m the author of the humorous children’s novel, The Annoying Ghost Kid. It’s about a boy and a girl who are bullied by a ghost. Most bullies must wait until there are no adults around before they can attack. The ghost-bully, however, has the power of invisibility which enables him to attack his victims in the classroom - right under the teacher’s nose! The kids have no one to turn to, so they have to figure out how to deal with the bully on their own.

As the author of The Annoying Ghost Kid, I am invited into many schools to make an “Author Visit.” As part of my presentation I talk about bullies and how to deal with them. I show the kids two easy-to-remember and simple-to-use techniques for fending off verbal and physical attacks. These techniques not only stop the bullies, but they begin the process of building self-esteem and self-confidence in the victims.


Here’s how you can help: the kids love my program; so do the teachers, librarians, counselors and principals at the schools. My presentation is fun, funny, informative and interactive (I have the kids practice the techniques). Here’s the problem: there are many schools that would like me to visit, but they can’t afford it. When you sponsor me, I’ll be able to teach thousands of kids how to deal with bullies - how to live free from fear!

Here's a clip from my presentation:

What We Need & What You Get

Schools learn about my program in one of two ways: word of mouth from a parent or a teacher, or I send them an email telling them about it. Both of these methods have a created a lot of interest in my program, and many schools want me to visit. I was surprised, however, to learn that many schools do not have the funding to bring me in.

Here is my goal: I am starting out with a modest request of $5000. For that amount I can visit up to 20 schools (depending on how much the schools contribute). Of course, the more I raise the more schools I can visit and the more kids I can help learn how to deal with bullies. Please be generous - I really want to help as many kids as possible learn how to stand up to a bully, so that they can go through life without fearing mean people.


(NOTE: on the scale of fees from other authors who visit schools, I am on the low end of the spectrum. I am also a professional speaker to adult audiences and what I charge schools is less than 10 percent of what I charge associations and corporations. For each school I deliver 2-3 presentations which run up to 45 minutes in length, I discount my books to less than half what they would normally pay, autograph and personalize them for each student. Plus, other services that meet the needs of particular schools. My point is that for a nominal fee, I offer a great value.)

Here’s what I want to give you for all of your help (see how to qualify for each one!): You’ll get my deepest gratitude and a shout out of thanks on Twitter and Facebook. I will be giving digital copies, printed copies, autographed copies, and even a few autographed, dated, and numbered author’s copies of The Annoying Ghost Kid. (If you don’t want or need a children’s book, I’ll also provide copies of my inspirational book: Wisdom in the Weirdest Places.) I will provide a group coaching session in dealing with bullies for the kid of your choice either via Skype or tele-conference line. A few people will get an exclusive one-on-one coaching session for their child (again via Skype or telephone).  If you don’t have a kid, there will be a group session, and a few one-on-one coaching sessions for adults in whichever of my areas of expertise you choose (please visit my website for more details: www.jumpstartyourmeeting.com) again this will be provided via Skype or telephone. You will also be able to sponsor my presentation to the elementary school of your choice anywhere in the world (via Skype), and anywhere in the contiguous United States (in person). 


    The Impact

    You’ve heard in the news what a big problem bullying has become lately. Part of my motivation in running this campaign is to create awareness of my program so that I can take it to more schools, and help more kids. Please tell your local school about it. Or send me their contact information (email is best), and I will reach out to them.

    Most schools have a “No Bullying” policy. Some schools even offer an Anti-Bullying program. The problem with most of these policies and programs is that they do not teach kids how to stand up to a bully. They teach victims to avoid bullies and to tattle on them. Realistically this only perpetuates the problem.

    The typical Anti-Bullying program tries to teach kids not to be bullies. While I applaud these efforts they will always fall short because it is the victim who needs to learn not to be a victim. I’m not saying that the victim is to blame, but simply that bullies do not pick on strong confident people. They don’t attack the strong and confident because the bully himself feels weak and insecure. It is the attacking of someone weak and defenseless that makes the bully feel powerful. I have written extensively about bullying for Psychology Today, please see this article: http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-main-ingredient/201312/bullies-and-victims-are-opposite-sides-the-same-coin

    My goal is to give potential victims the mental tools they need to halt a bully attack in its tracks. My techniques are simple-to-use and easy-to-remember, so that when a bully attacks, the victim will not panic and will be able to resolve it peacefully.

    To date, I have presented my program in several elementary schools reaching approximately 25,000 kids. Here’s what some of the educators have to say about it:

    "We really enjoyed your visit to our school on Tuesday. We really liked the way you not only entertained, but gave students some easy, practical things they can do to begin writing and to combat bullies." Cindy Adair, Media Specialist, Flippen Elementary School

    "Our elementary school had a great experience during a two-day visit with author Rob Wilson. Mr. Wilson was enthusiastic and engaging as he spoke with students about his book The Annoying Ghost Kid, on being an author, and how to deal with bullies. We recommend Mr. Wilson for your school's next guest author!" Diane Brooks, PTA President, Cheatham Hill Elementary

    “Rob was awesome today!  He spoke to the whole Lower School and everyone loved him!  He talked about bullying, read from his book, and was so animated!” Alisa Alloy, Teacher, The Howard School

    “I had the privilege of Rob Wilson coming to my school, and all the kids loved it. In one session, he captivated the entire audience, who ranged from first grade all the way to fifth grade. Every single student was captivated by his animated voice and lively reading of The Annoying Ghost Kid. In addition to the fabulous storytelling, the students all came away with an important message about bullying, which is so important to talk about nowadays.”  Katherine Fowler, Media Specialist, Ison Springs Elementary.

      Risks & Challenges

      I have been bullied. As a kid, I was harassed, beaten, threatened, ridiculed and shamed. I recall in vivid detail fearing walking to and from school, and taking different routes to avoid running into kids who had bullied me. Please read this article I wrote for Psychology Today where I tell of my personal experience with being bullied: http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-main-ingredient/201004/keep-your-power

      Perhaps being ridiculed and shamed was the worst. Those painful memories have had long term effects on my life. Many of my decisions and choices in life have been made in order to NEVER experience those feelings again. If you’ve ever experienced that - you know what I’m talking about. As a professional speaker to adults, I frequently tell my audiences to be more bold and to take more risks in life because of the many rewards that will come your way if you do. But, I tell them this knowing that many - like me - fear being bold because of their deep seated fears that hark back to a schoolyard memory of having been bullied with ridicule.

      Bullying is not going away. It is endemic to our society. We live in a system that encourages and rewards bullies. That is why it is so important for children to learn how to stand up to a bully. And, the younger they can learn it the better, because as you get older, the bullies get meaner and sneakier. Plus, it is easier to learn when you are young before you establish a victim mentality. Here’s another article I wrote for Psychology Today which expands on these thoughts: http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-main-ingredient/201210/we-empower-bullies-our-admiration

      I hope to raise much more than $5000 because I want to share my message and my techniques with as many children as possible. Please be as generous as you can. Thank you!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't contribute, that’s OK, because you can still help by making NOISE about this campaign:

      Please tell everyone you know about this campaign to raise funding.

      And, you can help spread the word about my school presentations. The more schools that know about it the better. Tell your friends with kids to tell their children’s teachers. If you know a teacher, school counselor, librarian or principal, please tell them about it - or give me their contact info (email is best), and I’ll send them an information package with all the details of my presentation. I’ll be happy to email it to you, so that you can forward it.

      Please post a link to this campaign on your Facebook and LinkedIn profiles. Use the hashtag: #bullybackoff. Tweet it on Twitter! Send emails to your friends and family. And use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hello! my name is Sam Laughter, I'm a kid who is 12 years of age and is entering the 8th grade! And I love to code/create games and webpages!

I am campaigning about a computer I hope to make, I will be buying all the parts needed to create a successful computer in the gaming/coding category! This project is very important to me because I think I can make a great profession out of it!

If I reach my goal that would be the best thing I could ever ask for because I would hope you guys would realize you just did a great thing to help a kid follow his dream!

Funding: I will need about 500 dollars to get my dream on track, and to create a successful computer. Thank you -Sam

story:
Short Summary

Help us get YES Scotland campaign leaflets out to local communities. 

What We Need

With your help, we would like to make sure everyone who wants them has YES leaflets and window posters to pass to their friends, family, workmates etc.  Our campaign is to mail out small packages of leaflets and window posters FREE OF CHARGE, especially to people in more isolated situations.

Please consider making a contribution to our mailing costs.  Your donation will help these leaflets and posters be distributed and seen thoughout the length and breadth of Scotland! 

This "Free leaflet campaign" parallels our previous "Free badge campaign". 

You can see more details of the materials available on our web page at http://yes.scotfolk.org.  

Soon, if funds permit, we will decorate our "battle van" to support the Yes campaign and drive round wherever we can. We will also equip local stalls with helium-filled balloons to add a bit of fun!

At the end of the campaign, we will publish a spreadsheet of our expenses there.

The Impact

With your help, YES Scotland's message of hope and confidence can spread all over Scotland.  Everyone's vote counts, so let's get out there!

Other Ways You Can Help!

Please pass this message on to anyone who might be in a position to help, either financially or just by spreading the word.  Sharing with friends on Facebook, Twitter and other social media, or even just mentioning it in the pub helps to get us closer to a win in September's Referendum!

Check out our web page - http://yes.scotfolk.org

story:
I've been invited to the Round Table with a sizable endowment, but I need to outfit myself with horse and armor, lance and sword.

Or in other words, I have the opportunity to attend a summer programme (course) on Arthurian legend at University of Exeter, and they've offered me a partial scholarship of $1300, but I still need to pay for the remainder of the tuition, airfare, books, and travel/day-trip money.


  • The Academic:

EDIT: Today, April 25, I found out I've been elected as one of two student representatives on the advisory committee for the Medieval Studies Certificate Program at the CUNY Graduate Center, a post I will hold from Fall 2014 through Spring 2016. 

When I began my first semester in an English PhD program this past September, I had the chapter headings and informal abstracts for my dissertation planned out.

It was going to be a survey of Arthurian legend in literature and culture from the Middle Ages right up to contemporary Young Adult literature. 

And then I started classes. With the inundation of ideas, texts, modes of thinking, angles and entryways, and just so many choices - so many choices! - I realized that my dissertation is very likely not going to focus exclusively on Arthur.

But though I've become interested in many new theories, approaches, genres, and texts, my love for Arthurian legend hangs on.

My one-liner about what I study is bound to change at least a little over the next few years, but right now it's that:

  • I study medieval literature, particularly Middle English and Anglo-Norman romance, looking at the construction, maintenance, and fluidity of boundaries, and the translations, transformations, conversions, and adaptations that occur across those boundaries.

I look for differences and similarities as expressed in literature along many kinds of lines (for example: social, cultural, gendered, linguistic, biological, geographical, national, temporal) and am tentatively calling myself a medieval postcolonialist and posthumanist. 

Arthurian legend fits into that perfectly.

My undergraduate senior thesis examined the cultural differences that went into the writing and reading of "cognate" tales in the Old French collection of Chretien de Troyes and the Old Welsh collection of the Mabinogion. 

This is what my shelf looked like as I worked on my thesis:


  • The Fangirl:

I was introduced to King Arthur with Mark Twain's A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court, which I read when I was 11. And 12. And 13. .... I got to the point where I could quote from it.

If I'd kept track of my library loans, which I really wish I had, I would know exactly which Arthurian Young Adult fantasy books I've read over the years.

A few months ago, I attended a talk by a "knight" who belongs to the Society for Creative Anachronism and heard fascinating details about how groups of adults get together regularly to engage in mock battles and jousts. 

It was just a lot of fun, but the part that stuck with me most was that the knight waxed poetic about how chivalric ideals feature prominently in his life.


The knight who spoke (Captain Zorikh) is on the left, joined by a fellow jouster. The talk was in a Queens, NY, bookstore and we then stepped outside for a demonstration. The two knights showed us moves and explained both how modern "knights" ensure safety and how these moves fit in with medieval jousting practice. 

We attracted quite a large crowd, standing on a busy Queens street, lots of amused onlookers, and some kids who clamored for a chance to hold the weapons - which they got!


  • The Fangirl-Academic

And that's just it - as a scholar of literature, and especially medieval literature, I'm very often asked to justify what I do. See above. 

When something hangs on through the ages with the tenacity Arthurian legend and tradition does, it has to have significance for the present and for the future. I want to be able to enter into and contribute to the conversation about what that significance is.

After this course/programme, I will be able to use what I've learned to inform my future work, and my hope is still that I will have at least one chapter of my dissertation devoted to Arthurian legend.


WHAT I NEED:

What I need for this vital step in my academic career is (after a scholarship of 

£800, about $1300):

  • £1645 to complete the tuition (about $2800). 
  • for lunches (and coffee!) not provided by the program, about $200.
  • about $1500 for airfare. UPDATE: I have now booked my flight. I shopped around and managed to get a great flight for $1300!! I still need help from you wonderful people for that, but I've saved $200 from my budget, which is really awesome.
  • Since I also plan to travel a bit in the UK on my own and visit Caerleon and Merlin's grave, and to hop over to France and visit (aside from Paris, obviously) places like Champagne, where the patroness of Chretien de Troyes' Lancelot lived, and Poitiers, where the "courts of love" were ostensibly held, I also need a bit of travel money. 

The course will take place during the month of July. I need to respond to accept the offer of place and scholarship with  

  • a non-refundable deposit of £250 ($420) by April 25 
  • and the rest, £1395 ($2300), by May 23. 
  • And of course, I need to book my flight as soon as possible, which as of now is about $1500. UPDATE: The flight is booked for $1300, and the date by which I need to pay it off is flexible.


WHAT YOU GET:

The perks I'm offering are:

  • $10 - a postcard mailed from the UK during my stay, with details of what I've been doing/reading
  • $25 - a souvenir (bought while I'm there, mailed when I get back). You can request a specific type and/or theme and I will do my best to find that!
  • $50 - a poem personalized for you or for someone you want to give it to
  • $100 - a short story personalized for you or for someone you want to give it to
  • $500 - my services as an editor and/or copyeditor 


AND FINALLY:

I will post an update about what I've gained from my trip when I get back, and maybe I'll do a vlog as well, which I will share with all of you here.

And really, that's more of a "perk" for me, because I'd get to talk about all my ideas more and have a wider audience.

When I'm passionate about something, I could go on forever about it. And I'm definitely passionate about literature, about cultural history, about Arthur.

story: Global Innovation Now Tech camp is raising funds to enable the opportunity for any child registered to attend the camp. The funds will sponsor 30 kids to learn graphic design, website developing,how mobile apps work,apps that teach foreign languages, fitness, and finances in the 1 week program. The children will also receive a tech camp pack with all essential needs such as laptop bag, pens/pencils, journal, writing pads, and tablets or laptops (if sponsored). The tech camp is a program in which each registered participant(s) ages 8-18 can be educated on a different topics which is a centralized subject specific to that app, yet correlates with the other courses in the tech camp (i.e. Technology, Fitness, Finance, and Foreign Languages). The children will be involved in team work, team building, and team tech creations, in each children will learn how to work with others in a team atmosphere. All children involved in the camp will be awarded at the end of the term. The Tech Camp ends we can research, organize, and strategically restructure all courses to have a even more innovative tech camp in which kids will grow and learn from upon the next 6 weeks to start another mobile app tech camp. Thank you for your support and thanks in advance!

story:
Going to China in 2015!

Hello friends and family,

I am planning on going to Nanjing, China from March 17th to the 30th with my school, PK Yonge DRS. It will be an international travel and I plan on learning about the communication along with the other many differences between the US and China. My schoolmates and I will be staying at the homes of students from our partner school in Nanjing, China. Previously, this year we hosted at our homes students from the partner school in Nanjing. The students lived in our homes to experience the way people live in America, and attended our school to observe our education processes and to practice their English.

I am extremely excited about this trip because it is international and to China. Not only does China have the largest spoken first language in the world, Mandarin, it has a vast variety of culture and education differences from the US that I wish to learn about and experience firsthand.

What I Require By February 5th

  • Airfare: $1,800
  • Visa: $250
  • Day in Shanghai: $250
  • Administration fee: $200

Total cost of trip: $2,500; Currently the amount I need to raise is approximately $1800. Daily, I will update needed balance on my site.

 What You Get

In addition to getting my everlasting thanks for every contribution made, you will also get different perk(s) depending on the amount donated.
  • For $15 you will receive the password to my invite only blog where I will be posting events I do in China
  • For $25 you will receive a link to a photo album with pictures from the trip as well as the password to my blog
  • For $50 you will receive a postcard from either Nanjing or Shanghai as well as the link to the photo album and the password to my blog
  • For $100 you will receive a trinket from China along with the password to my blog AND online photo album.

The Impact

When the trip is done and I'm back home, I will look back on this trip as a once in a lifetime opportunity. I will have had the unique experience at having seen what China is like in culture and history first hand.

Other Ways You Can Help

All money raised is going straight into funding for my trip. Please remember that giving any amount of money helps but it is not the only way to assist me with my trip; by letting others know about me and my trip will help me get a long way towards my goal.

I thank you all for your help and time at getting me to China.

story:
HELP OPEN UNITY PERFORMING ARTS AND CAREER CENTER!!

As you may have heard, the community needs your support to help renovate the inside of the new Unity Performing Arts and Career Center (UPACC) , so that we can open the doors Spring 2014.  DONATE ANY AMOUNT!!

Your generous contribution will help build a stronger community by providing a needed community learning space that will improve education, health and family self-sufficiency. Unity Performing Arts and Career Center (UPACC), is fiscally sponsored project of Metanoia Center of Innovation a 501.3C not-for-profit organization.  

                                         DONATE ANY AMOUNT!!

FOR BUSINESS SPONSORSHIP INFORMATION, or to schedule a pre-construction tour visit unitypacc.org or email unitypacc@gmail.com.  

                                         DONATE ANY AMOUNT!!

Location: 2001 S. Philo Rd., Urbana, IL 61803

Mail: P.O. Box 531, Urbana, IL 61803

Phone: 217-298-2177

story:
Hi my name is Stacey Holmes, 

I am a sound engineering student from Glasgow.  

Www.soundcloud.com/novelistt 

I have been making my own music living on the breadline for a while and before I started my current course I couldn't Read, spell or understand any written document 

After 6 weeks at college I passed my intermediate 2 English exam 2 weeks before the rest of the class, and now I enjoy reading  books and understanding  many things in life  making my life so much easier. I am supported with  BBC radio 1xtra via #targetsnoticeboard  and  my  Fans are worldwide  but my music ain't  at the best quality levels yet, so I applied to access to music college in London to study their artist development course, after they followed  me  on my twitter,, the same day the called me back, and we spoke about what benefits  this course would give me, and also to arrange a meeting with me when I am at the BBC studios this month  (feb) , and we discussed my life and future plans and living arrangements .

Clearly the major  part of being accepted to London is securing a home for me and my 1 year old  son , I only have a little  savings but will be continuing to save before June,  my friend Jamie told me to reach  out and ask for some crowd  funding, this brought me here!

Studying  for a  rock school  level. 4 diploma  is something I could only have dreamed  of doing,  nor did I think I would be in the position I am in now! 

ON THE 20TH FEB I GOT MY PLACEMENT I START IN SEPTEMBER !

What We Need & What You Get

  • I need. £1,000  for a months rent in advance and deposit.
  • This will secure  my home for me and my son in order for me to find him a nursery and start my course in September.
  • you will have bragging rights in the future when my career is elevated.
  • If I do not reach the full goal what ever has been funded will still go to the rent and deposit .

The Impact

  • If you contribute to helping Gain the education  I require to further my music career this will have a massive beneficial affect to  my family's  life as your could imagine .

Other Ways You Can Help

Please could you share this campaign  with anyone who you know that could help! Maybe a landlord with a great flat  in Central London  that would not be looking for a deposit or who would allow me to pay it up while in the tenancy . 

Thanks everyone! 

Stacey & Jack.

story:
Campaign Countdown

The Saving Lives Indiegogo campaign ends in 13 hours. Thank you to everyone for your awesome support! We raised over $6,500! This will allow us to start working on the roof. Please visit us at savinglives.kheprw.org. Or stop by  to find out more about our work and the youth center.

       


Mat's Experiences

    

Meet Mat, age 22.  Hear about his experiences at the Kheprw Institute and what he gained from his involvement! Support KI Saving Lives.



Empowering Black Youth Since 2004

The Kheprw Institute (KI) is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization established in 2004. We strive to provide experiences and opportunities for youth and adults to bring forth the best within themselves, to constantly development and enhance their abilities, to take responsibility for their own transformation and to make positive contributions to their community. We do this by focusing on:

  • Education-  With a focus on African American males, we mentor and educate youth, teaching entrepreneurship, science and technology.
  • Empowerment- Youth gain critical thinking and public speaking skills by researching and presenting at monthly public forums on topics which have included: Ferguson, climate change, education, and more.
  • Environment and Economy- Youth learn about both sustainability and entrepreneurship through our urban agriculture projects and businesses including the Urban Agriculture Science Lab, KI Compost, Express Yourself Rain Barrels and KI Aquaponics.

Challenges

On a daily basis young black men's lives are in danger. We do not have THE answer to changing such a huge societal problem. Our focus is to make an impact on the lives of the youth in our program and trust them to create a better future. 



The Vision for KI's Youth Center

We strive to build a community:

  • Where multiple generations learn from, teach and support one another.
  • That is empowered and organized to overcome economic and environmental challenges of today and tomorrow.
  • That is informed and connected to local and global issues.
  • Where youth are nurtured to become the leaders we need.

It's our dream to open a new community center in our neighborhood dedicated to youth. We own a vacant house that will fit our vision, and with your help we can make this vision a reality. 



Our Youth Center will Provide... 

  • Housing for local and international youth interns and young entrepreneurs.
  • Creative space to launch new businesses, acquire skills and hold community conversations.
  • A model of sustainability with solar panels, rain barrels and urban agriculture projects.

Invest in Our Future

Youth are our future. It's up to us to equip them to face the incredible challenges facing us. Your contribution will change lives and allow us to continue providing one-on-one mentorship and educational opportunities to youth in our neighborhood. 

Perks

[Descriptions on the right]

Project Budget

We value your support and trust, so we are striving to be transparent about this project. If we are able to reach our goal here is an outline about how the project will use the funds we raise:

  • New Roof and Gutters - $12,000
  • Exterior Renovation - $5,000
  • Interior Renovation - $10,000
  • Plumbing - $3,000
  • Electrical - $1,000
  • Furnace - $5,000
  • Deck - $2,000
  • Kitchen - $4,000
  • Furniture - $2,000
  • Computers - $5,000
  • Video Equipment - $5,000
  • Solar Panels - $15,000
  • Urban Agriculture Projects - $6,000
  • TOTAL = $75,000

Please Help Spread the Word

In addition to making a contribution, here are some other ways you can help make our campaign successful:

  1. Email your friends and family a link to the campaign. Look below for a template you can use.
  2. Press the Facebook and Twitter share buttons above to spread the word about our campaign! Below are some sample messages you can post and tweet.


Email Template 


Hi [name of friend, family, loved one],


I saw this campaign and it really inspired me. I thought you'd be interested in the cause and might want to support it. The campaign is focused on saving the lives of young African American males. The organization focuses on mentoring youth and empowering them to become critical thinkers and entrepreneurs. 

They are raising money to build a new youth center where they can provide housing and creative space for youth to acquire skills and start their own businesses. Here is a link to the campaign: savinglives.kheprw.org

Thanks for your support! Also please help spread the word and forward this to your friends and family.


Twitter

#SavingLives & empowering African American youth @kheprw! Check out crowd-funding campaign on @indiegogo http://igg.me/p/960558/twtr/884686


Facebook Post

I saw this campaign and it really inspired me. It's focused on saving the lives of young African American males. The organization focuses on mentoring youth and empowering them to become critical thinkers and entrepreneurs. They are raising money to open a new youth center where they can provide housing and creative space for youth to acquire skills and start their own businesses.

 Check it out and please support!

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/960558/fblk
story_txt:
Campaign Countdown
The Saving Lives Indiegogo campaign ends in 13 hours. Thank you to everyone for your awesome support! We raised over $6,500! This will allow us to start working on the roof. Please visit us at savinglives.kheprw.org. Or stop by  to find out more about our work and the youth center.
       

Mat's Experiences
    
Meet Mat, age 22.  Hear about his experiences at the Kheprw Institute and what he gained from his involvement! Support KI Saving Lives.




Empowering Black Youth Since 2004 
The Kheprw Institute (KI) is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization established in 2004. We strive to provide experiences and opportunities for youth and adults to bring forth the best within themselves, to constantly development and enhance their abilities, to take responsibility for their own transformation and to make positive contributions to their community. We do this by focusing on:


Education-  With a focus on African American males, we mentor and educate youth, teaching entrepreneurship, science and technology.

Empowerment- Youth gain critical thinking and public speaking skills by researching and presenting at monthly public forums on topics which have included: Ferguson, climate change, education, and more.

Environment and Economy- Youth learn about both sustainability and entrepreneurship through our urban agriculture projects and businesses including the Urban Agriculture Science Lab, KI Compost, Express Yourself Rain Barrels and KI Aquaponics.


Challenges
On a daily basis young black men's lives are in danger. We do not have THE answer to changing such a huge societal problem. Our focus is to make an impact on the lives of the youth in our program and trust them to create a better future. 













The Vision for KI's Youth Center
 We strive to build a community:


Where multiple generations learn from, teach and support one another.

That is empowered and organized to overcome economic and environmental challenges of today and tomorrow.


That is informed and connected to local and global issues.

Where youth are nurtured to become the leaders we need.


It's our dream to open a new community center in our neighborhood dedicated to youth. We own a vacant house that will fit our vision, and with your help we can make this vision a reality. 




Our Youth Center will Provide... 
 

Housing for local and international youth interns and young entrepreneurs. 
Creative space to launch new businesses, acquire skills and hold community conversations. 
A model of sustainability with solar panels, rain barrels and urban agriculture projects.

story:
Who am I and What am I doing?!

My name is Shannon Todd and I have been involved with Ainembabazi Children's Project since 2008 when I interned in Uganda. I fell in love with the country, our community members and our mission.

I am raising money to help support our current livestock and agricultural programming. This programming is essential because it helps out community members become self-sustaining and improve their quality of life. 

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking 150 people to donate $10 each to provide experts in the livestock and agricultural fields to train 150 of our community members. Your $10 will go directly to educating one of our community members.  

For your donation you will receive a charitable receipt. If I reach my goal of funding this project by Sept. 6, I am challenging myself to kayak the North Saskatchewan from Drayton Vally to Devon with Renee Vaugeois, our President. As many of you know I am not really a 'water sports' person so this will be a major challenge for me! It will test us physically and mentally. 

    The Impact

    By bringing in experts in the fields of agriculture and livestock rearing to teach our community members we hope they will have increased yields and improved/maintained livestock health. 

    Some recent successes of our programming: 

    - Kinoni community garden harvested 80kg of beans. They sold 50kg for profit and kept 30kg to plant in the next season. 

    - Families in all communities that were given livestock have passed on the offspring livestock to the next families in line. 

    - Kitwe community garden harvested 2 sacks of ground nuts (similar to peanuts) and 1 basin of peas.

      Risks & Challenges

      Quite frankly I'm totally scared of rivers and water sports. So I suppose the risk is that I'll have a really hard time on the river! 

      Ainembabazi Children's Project is 100% volunteer so you can count on all of your dollars hitting the ground in Uganda.  

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Consider joining us on our river trip!

story:
Bonus Stretch Goal - SLE Chess Library

(see Updates for more info) 

Short Summary

The South Lakewood Elementary Chess Club needs your help. We are  a growing  Chess Club for young players. We meet once a week before school to learn and play the game. Our boards are beginning to show their age and we are ready to step up to using timers and keeping logs of our games. We need your help to get these things. 

What We Need  

  • New and standardized boards
  • Chess clocks
  • Log books 
  • A Demonstration board

What You Get

  • Future Chess opponents
  • Our thanks

The Impact

Over the last two years we have grown but our equipment has not. Not only are the boards wearing out but we sometimes have more players than boards. By helping us we will be getting standardized boards, timers and materials to log our games. 

This will help us become better players.  Thank you.

The South Lakewood Elementary Chess Club Students  

Tl;dr

Tom here, one of the Dads who runs this Chess Club. The words above are the collected expression of the kids who make up the Chess Club, They  play hard, they learn the moves but they really want to take it up a notch. They need new boards, they need more boards, they need the clocks so the games do not go on till the class bell and they need to log their games so they can learn form them. They are willing to put in the time and work but they need our help to get the tools to do it.  On behalf of all of us who are running the Chess Club we want to thank you for your help and know that someday in the not to distant future the fruits of  your support might just be staring you in the face across a chess board. 

The South Lakewood Elementary Chess Club Staff
